Implementation Notes: Administration amount that was given to the subject. \n Note: Should not be the diluent amount alone. The ECTRTV field may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of measurement for the prepared product (treatment + vehicle).
Question Text: What was the unit for the amount (of [study treatment/dose]) administered?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit of total amount (treatment +vehicle) administered/given to the subject (e.g., mL).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Unit of the administration amount

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The flow rate for the total amount of drug + vehicle administered to the subject.
Question Text: What was the [study treatment/dose] infusion rate?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the Rate of Infusion (e.g., if rate is 10 mL/min. Record 10 as the infusion rate).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEC dataset as the value of SUPPEC.QVAL where SUPPEC.QNAM="ECFLRT" and SUPPEC.QLABEL= "Infusion Rate". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: The infusion rate can be used to derive dose.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Exposure as Collected Infusion Rate Unit
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of measure for the flow rate for the total amount of drug + vehicle administered to the subject.
Question Text: What was the unit for the ([study treatment/dose]) infusion rate?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit for the infusion rate (e.g., mL/min).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEC dataset as the value of SUPPEC.QVAL where SUPPEC.QNAM="ECFLRTU" and SUPPEC.QLABEL= "Infusion Rate Unit". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: Unit of the infusion rate

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of the planned time point when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point for [study treatment/dose]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time point of study treatment administration if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTMIG time-point anchors ECTPTREF (text description) and ECRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables ECTPTNUM, ECELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a field that requires the site to enter text. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the subject completed the intended regimen.
Question Text: Did the subject complete the full course of [study treatment/dose]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select either Yes or No to indicate whether subject has completed the full course of treatment.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEC dataset as the value of SUPPEC.QVAL where SUPPEC.QNAM = "ECTRTCMP" and SUPPEC.QLABEL ="Completed Treatment". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: Depending on how the study treatment details are collected on the CRF/eCRF, it may be possible to derive those data if the regimen data are collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Name of the trial epoch with which this element of the arm is associated.
Question Text: What is the trial epoch?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: [protocol specific]
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: If the same information is collected more than once in different periods/parts of a study (e.g., Disposition), EPOCH may be needed to differentiate them. Typically, the trial epoch will be preprinted on the CRF as the title of the page. See the SDTMIG for further information regarding EPOCH.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the subject took study medication/treatment.
Question Text: Were any[study treatment/dose] taken?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the subject took any study medications. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank. The EXYN variable is a cleaning or EDC convention meant to indicate that the exposure form should be completed or inserted into the case book.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the [study treatment/dose] ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the study treatment category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the EXCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory of the [study treatment/dose] ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the study treatment subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. EXSCAT can only be used if there is an EXCAT and it must be a subcategorization of EXCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Name of the study treatment or intervention given per single administration or during the constant dosing interval for the observation.
Question Text: What was the [study treatment/investigational product] name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of study treatment.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: EXTRT captures the name of the investigational treatment. This is typically collected for open label studies and populated for blinded studies during the SDTM-based dataset creation. Because EXTRT is the SDTMIG topic variable, it is a required variable in SDTM and must have a value in CDASH or a plan to populate it in the SDTM submission datasets (i.e., collected or populated from other sources).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier (e.g., kit number, bottle label, vial identifier).
Question Text: What is the [study treatment/dose] label identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record treatment label identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This packaging identifier (e.g., kit number, bottle label, vial identifier) may be collected in different ways (e.g., affixing label onto CRF, scanning a bar code). For some study dosing regimens, greater granularity for treatment identifiers may be needed.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Lot number of the EXTRT product.
Question Text: What was the lot number of the[study treatment/dose] used?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the lot number that appears on the container holding the study treatment.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The lot number identifies the manufacturing batch of the study treatment. In open-label studies, the reference number on the study treatment container may represent an actual lot number and is submitted using EXLOT. This variable may be populated during the process of creating the SDTM submission datasets. Do not collect other identification variables in this field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time.
Question Text: Was the subject fasting?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether the subject was fasting prior to the study treatment being taken.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Because some study treatments may have a food effect, it is important to know whether the dose was taken after the subject had fasted.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dosage form in which the EXTRT is physically presented.
Question Text: What was the dose form of the [study treatment/dose] ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the dose form (e.g., SOLUTION, TABLET, LOTION) or enter the appropriate code from the code list.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This must be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources or if there are multiple options.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start date of study treatment, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the ([intended/planned/actual]) ([study treatment/dose]) (start) date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the start date of the study treatment administration using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EXSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: Date when the constant dosing interval of the study treatment started or single administration occurred. When collecting the date for an individual dose, the word "start" may be omitted from the question text and prompt.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start time of the study treatment, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the ([intended/planned/actual]) ([study treatment/dose]) (start) time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the start time (as complete as possible) when administration of study treatment started.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EXSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: Recommend collecting the time a medication was started only when a protocol or data collection scenario requires it.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end date of study treatment, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the ([intended/planned/actual]) ([study treatment/dose]) (end) date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the end date or last date of administration of study treatment using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EXENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: If start date and end date are not expected to be on the same date, the end date is required. If the study design indicates that the start and end date are on the same day, the end date is not required because it can be assigned to be equal to the start date.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end time of treatment, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the ([intended/planned/actual]) ([study treatment/dose]) (end) time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time, (as complete as possible) when study treatment administration stopped (e.g., for infusions this is the time when the infusion ended).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EXENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: Recommend collecting the time a medication was ended when a protocol or data collection scenario requires it. For infusions, the end time of the infusion is typically needed.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Dose (per administration).
Question Text: What was the dose [per administration] (of [study treatment/dose]) ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the dose or amount of study treatment that was administered to/taken by the subject in the period recorded; from the start date/time to the end date/time inclusive.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Numeric values map to EXDOSE in SDTM. Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to EXDOSTXT in SDTM.
Implementation Notes: Dose or amount taken for single administration of study treatment or per constant dosing interval recorded. Dose must be collected if it cannot be determined via other methods (e.g., from diary data, drug accountability data, protocol). The data collected in this dose text-format field should be mapped to either SDTMIG variable EXDOSE (if numeric) or EXDOSTXT (if text).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit for intended dose (per administration) for EXDOSE, EXDOSTOT, or EXDOSTXT.
Question Text: What was the unit for the dose?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit of dose or amount taken per period recorded (e.g., ng, mg, mg/kg).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Unit of dose or amount taken per constant dosing interval recorded. Dose unit must be collected if it cannot be determined via other methods (e.g., from protocol, randomization data). The unit should be preprinted on the CRF or a field provided on the CRF to capture it. A CDASH Subset Controlled Terminology Codelist Name is available for general dose and volume units.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The number of doses given/administered/taken during a specific interval.
Question Text: What was the frequency of[study treatment/dose] dosing?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the frequency the study treatment was administered for a defined period of time.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources or if there are multiple options. When possible, the options for dose/amount frequency are preprinted on the CRF. When collected, the recommendation is to collect dosing information in separate fields (e.g., ECDOSE, ECDOSEU, ECDOSFRQ) for specific and consistent data collection and to enable programmatically using these data.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The route of administration of the study treatment.
Question Text: What was the route of administration (of the [study treatment/dose] )?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the route of administration (e.g., IV, ORAL, TRANSDERMAL) or enter the appropriate code from the code list.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This may be collected if it cannot be determined via other methods (e.g., from protocol) or if there are multiple options.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The text description of the intended schedule or regimen for the Intervention.
Question Text: What was the intended dose regimen (of the [study treatment/dose] )?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the regimen for the study medication.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The regimen information may further clarify the dose administration and dose frequency (e.g., TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF). This may be preprinted or collected. The sponsor may wish to create a codelist to collect this data consistently.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the dose was adjusted.
Question Text: Was the dose adjusted?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select either Yes or No to indicate whether there was a change in dosing.
Mapping Instructions: When EXADJ is collected, does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED. When EXADJ is not collected, the sponsor may submit this variable as a SUPPQ.
Implementation Notes: Typically, the intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring, as it provides a definitive response regarding any dose changes. It provides verification that the associate field on the CRF (EXADJ) was deliberately left blank. However, the sponsor may collect whether the dose was adjusted, without collecting the reason for the change.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Description of or explanation for why a dose of the study treatment was adjusted.
Question Text: What was the reason the dose was adjusted (from planned)?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If there was a change in dosing, record the reason for change.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Captures the reason the dose was changed or modified. The reason may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., adverse event, insufficient response) or entered as free text. May be used for variations from protocol-specified doses or changes from expected doses.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the exposure was interrupted.
Question Text: Was the [ (study) treatment/dose] interrupted?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record if there was an interruption in the study treatment or dosing.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring when the actual duration of the exposure is collected using the CDASH field EXCINTD. In some situations, if the actual duration of the interruption is not collected, or not derived, this information could be submitted in a SUPPEX.QVAL dataset where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXITRPYN" and SUPPEX.QLABEL = "Exposure Interrupted".

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The collected duration of the treatment interruption.
Question Text: If the dose was interrupted, how long was the interruption?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the duration of treatment interruption.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM="EXITRPD" and SUPPEX.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected treatment interruption duration and the duration unit components and create EXITRPD using ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: In some situations, the duration of the interruption may be calculated from the administration start and end times recorded elsewhere in the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit for the collected duration of treatment interruption.
Question Text: If the dose was interrupted, what were the units for the interruption duration?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit (e.g., MINUTES, HOURS, DAYS) for the duration of treatment interruption.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXITRPD" and SUPPEX.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected treatment interruption duration and the duration unit components and create EXITRPDusing ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: The unit should be collected and converted into ISO 8601 period format.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A description of the anatomical location of administration.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location of the ([study treatment/dose] ) administration?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the body location where the study treatment was administered (e.g., SHOULDER, HIP, ARM).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or preprinted when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location where the study treatment was administered. LAT, DIR, PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The amount of the prepared product (treatment + vehicle) administered or given.
Question Text: What was the total amount (Drug + Vehicle)(of [study treatment/dose] ) administered?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the total amount (treatment +vehicle) that was administered/given to the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTM variable ECTRTV may also be populated during the process of creating the SDTM submission datasets.
Implementation Notes: Administration amount that was given to the subject. Note: should not be the diluent amount alone. The ECTRTV field may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of measure for the prepared product (treatment + vehicle).
Question Text: What was the unit for the amount (of [study treatment/dose] ) administered?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit of total amount (treatment +vehicle) administered/given to the subject (e.g., mL).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Unit of the administration amount. A CDASH Subset Controlled Terminology Codelist Name is available for dose and volume units.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The flow rate for the total amount of drug + vehicle administered to the subject.
Question Text: What was the [study treatment/dose] infusion rate?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the Rate of Infusion (e.g., if rate is 10 mL/min. Record 10 as the infusion rate).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXFLRT" and SUPPEX.QLABEL= "Infusion Rate". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: The infusion rate can be used to derive dose.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of measure for the flow rate for the total amount of drug + vehicle administered to the subject.
Question Text: What were the units for the [study treatment/dose] infusion rate?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit for the infusion rate (e.g., mL/min).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM ="EXFLRTU" and SUPPEX.QLABEL="Infusion Rate Unit". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: Unit of the infusion rate

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of the planned time point when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point for [study treatment/dose] ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time point of study treatment administration if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTMIG time-point anchors EXTPTREF (text description) and EXRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables EXTPTNUM, EXELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a field that requires the site to enter text. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication of whether the subject completed the intended regimen.
Question Text: Did the subject complete the full course of [study treatment/dose] ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select either Yes or No to indicate whether subject has completed the full course of treatment.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPEX dataset as the value of SUPPEX.QVAL where SUPPEX.QNAM = "EXTRTCMP" and SUPPEX.QLABEL=" Completed Treatment". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: Depending on how the study treatment details are collected via the CRF/eCRF, it may be possible to derive those data if the regimen data are collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing side of the body for the study treatment administration.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the ([study treatment/dose] ) administration?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the body location where the study treatment was administered (e.g., Left, Right).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Further details the laterality of the location where the study treatment was administered. This may be preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the ([study treatment/dose] ) administration?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the body location where the study treatment was administered (e.g., Anterior, Lower, Proximal, Upper).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category for the [meal/food product]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [meal/food product] category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading, or a preprinted category value on the CRF and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the MLCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory for the [meal/food product]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [meal/food product] subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether any meal or food product were consumed or administered.
Question Text: [Were/Was] any [meal/food product] [taken/consumed/administered] ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the subject consumed any [meal/food product]. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile meal/food product records with AEs and/or MH. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Name of Meal or Food Product
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The reported name of the food, beverage or combination of food or beverage consumed at one time. \n
Question Text: What was the [meal/food product/sponsor-defined] (name)?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record only 1 [meal/food product name] per line.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsors may use the name of a food or the name of the combination of foods (e.g., breakfast, low-fat meal, breakfast bar, water). \n

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that a specific intervention or a group of interventions is prespecified on a CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: For prespecified interventions, a hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM dataset creation. If a study collects both prespecified and free-text interventions, the value of MLPRESP should be "Y" for all prespecified interventions and null for interventions reported as free text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the prespecified meal or food product were taken/consumed/administered when information about the occurrence of the specific intervention was solicited.
Question Text: Did the subject take [MLTRT]?; Has the subject [taken/consumed/administered] [MLTRT]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if [MLTRT] was [taken/consumed/administered] by checking Yes or No.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. If the question was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable MLSTAT with "NOT DONE".
Implementation Notes: MLOCCUR is used to report the occurrence of a prespecified meal/ food product. MLOCCUR is not used for spontaneously reported free-text meals/food products. The site should be able to indicate that the response was not asked or answered.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the scheduled intervention did or did not occur.
Question Text: What was the reason that the [MLTRT] was (not) consumed/taken/done/administered]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Reason [MLTRT] (Not) [Performed/Taken/Done/Administered]
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPML dataset as the value of SUPPML.QVAL where SUPPML.QNAM = "MLREASOC" and SUPPML.QLABEL ="Reason for Occur Value". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: The reason MLTRT occurred may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist or entered as free text. When --REASOC is used, --OCCUR must also be populated in the SDTM dataset. This variable should not be used to represent that the item was not answered, not done, not completed, or unknown. The variables MLSTAT /MLREASND should be used instead.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The reason that the meal/food product was used.
Question Text: What was the reason for the [meal/food product] [[taken/consumed/administered]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the reason the meal/product was taken.
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPML dataset as the value of SUPPML.QVAL where SUPPML.QNAM = "MLREAS" and SUPPML.QLABEL ="Reason for the Intervention". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: This is the condition, disease, symptom, or disorder for which the meal or food product is taken, consumed, or administered This additional information is collected on the CRF when sponsors want to capture the reason(s) why a subject took a meal/product.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Identifier for the clinical event event that is the indication for this meal or food product.
Question Text: What was the identifier for the clinical event s) for which the (meal/food product] was [taken/consumed/administered]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier of the Clinical Event for which this [meal/food product] was taken/consumed/administered.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the CE domain.
Implementation Notes: The intent is to establish a link between the meal/food product and a clinical event that was reported. MLCENO can be used to identify a relationship between records in ML dataset and records in the CE dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on RELREC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The quantity/amount of the meal or food product (e.g., --TRT) taken/consumed/administered represented as a numeric value.
Question Text: What was the quantity/amount (of the) ([meal/food product]) [taken/consumed/administered]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the quantity/amount of the meal/food product (e.g., --TRT ) given at one time represented as a numeric value.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used when the quantity taken/administered/consumed has only numeric entries. If non-numeric entries are possible, use the CDASH field MLDSTXT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The quantity/amount of the meal or food product (e.g., --TRT) taken/consumed/administered represented as a numeric or text value.
Question Text: What was quantity/amount (of the) ([meal/food product]) [taken/consumed/administered]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the quantity/amount of the [meal/food product] taken/consumed/administered at one time.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Numeric values map to MLDOSE in SDTM. Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to MLDOSTXT in SDTM.
Implementation Notes: Defining this data collection field as a text field allows for flexibility in capturing entries as numbers, text, or ranges. The data collected in this text-format field should be separated or mapped to either SDTMIG MLDOSE (if numeric) or MLDOSTXT (if text).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit associated with the quantity/amount of the the meal /food product taken/consumed/administered.
Question Text: What is the unit for the quantity/amount of the [meal/food product]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit for the quantity/amount of the [meal/food product] taken/consumed/administered.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: When sponsors collect data for amount /quantity of meal/food product taken (i.e., Dose, Total Daily Dose), the unit must be collected as well (if applicable).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start date when the meal or food product was first taken/consumed/administered, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date the [meal/food product] was first [taken/consumed/administered]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date the [meal/food product] was first taken/consumed/administered using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The assumption is that sponsors should either have a start date or will indicate that the meal or food product was started before, during, or after the study period. The preferred method is to collect a complete start date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only) for meal/food product started a considerable amount of time prior to the start of study are acceptable.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time the meal or food product was started, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the [meal/food product] start time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the [meal/food product] was started.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: Recommend collecting the time a meal/food product was started only when a protocol or data collection scenarios supports it. Typically, a start time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a meal/food product or the subject records the start time in a diary. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and the SDTMIG for more information.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date that the subject ended/stopped taking/consuming/administering the meal or food product product represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the [meal/food product] end date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date the [meal/food product] was stopped using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the subject has not stopped taking the [meal/product] leave this field blank.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The assumption is that sponsors should either have an end date or will indicate that the meal or food product was ongoing at the time of collection or at the end of the study. However, in cases where the end date can be determined from dates collected elsewhere in the CRF it is not necessary to include an end date in the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time when the subject ended/stopped taking the meal or food product represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the [meal/food product] end time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time (as complete as possible) that the [meal/food product] was stopped.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MLENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: Recommend collecting the time a meal/food product was ended only when a protocol or data collection scenarios require it or the subject records the start time in a diary. Typically, a end time is not collected unless the subject is under the direct care of the site at the time a meal/food product or the subject records the end time in a diary. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and the SDTMIG for more information.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary or sponsor-defined standardized text description of the topic variable (MLTRT) or the modified topic variable (MLMODIFY), if applicable.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. Equivalent to a standardized name in a published or sponsor-defined dictionaries.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: If the value for MLTRT is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF itself. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or created during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the subject had any procedures performed.
Question Text: Were any surgical, therapeutic, or diagnostic procedures performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the subject had any surgical, therapeutic or diagnostic procedures. If "Yes", include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the procedure?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the procedure category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the PRCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the procedure?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the procedure subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. PRSCAT can only be used if there is a PRCAT and it must be a subcategorization of PRCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, This is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile procedure records with medical history and/or with AEs. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g., line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The verbatim surgical, therapeutic, or diagnostic procedure's name.
Question Text: What was the procedure name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record only one procedure per line.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: In most cases, the verbatim procedure names or therapy will be coded to a standard dictionary (e.g., MedDRA, SNOMED) after the data have been collected on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary or sponsor-defined standardized text description of PRTRT, or the modified topic variable (PRMODIFY), if applicable.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is typically not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF. If the sponsor chooses to code the procedure, the sponsor will populate this through the coding process. If PRPRESP is used, and the information about a specific standardized procedure name is being solicited, the data from PRTRT may map directly to the SDTMIG PRDECOD variable.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: If the value for PRTRT is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF. If the sponsor chooses to code the procedure, the sponsor will populate this through the coding process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that a specific intervention or a group of interventions is prespecified on a CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: For prespecified interventions, a hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM dataset creation. If a study collects both prespecified and free-text interventions, the value of PRPRESP should be "Y" for all prespecified interventions and null for interventions reported as free text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a prespecified procedure (PRTRT) happened when information about the occurrence of a specific intervention is solicited.
Question Text: Was [PRDECOD/PRTRT] performed?; Has the subject had [PRDECOD/PRTRT]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if [specific procedure] was performed by checking Yes or No.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. If the response was not asked or answered, populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTAT with "NOT DONE".
Implementation Notes: PROCCUR is used to report the occurrence of a prespecified procedure or a group of procedures. PROCCUR is not used for spontaneously free text-reported procedures. The site should be able to indicate that the response was not asked or answered.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why a scheduled procedure did or did not occur.
Question Text: What was the reason that the procedure did or not occur?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate why the procedure did or did not occur.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason the scheduled procedure was or was not performed may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist (e.g., SUBJECT REFUSED) or entered as free text. When --REASOC is used, --OCCUR must also be populated in the SDTM dataset with a value of "Y" or "N".

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available.
Question Text: What was the reason not done?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason why the procedure was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When PRREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable PRSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset. The value "NOT DONE" here indicates that the subject was not questioned/data was not collected. It does not mean that the subject did not have the procedure.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication the procedure occurred prior to [PRSTTPT] or prior to the date in DM.RFSTDTC.
Question Text: Was the procedure performed prior to [PRSTTPT]?; Was the procedure performed prior to study start?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Check if the procedure was started before the specified point in time.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTM relative timing variable such as PRSTRF or PRSTRTPT. When populating PRSTRF, or PRSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field PRPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used. When PRPRIOR refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRSTRF should be populated. When PRPRIOR is compared to another time point, the SDTM variables PRSTRTPT and PRSTTPT should be used. Note: PRSTRTPT must refer to the time-point anchor described in PRSTTPT.
Implementation Notes: See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions , and and the SDTMIG for more information about mapping relative times. .

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date or start date of when the procedure started or was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the procedure (start) date ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date the procedure was started or performed using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). Procedures performed during the study are expected to have a complete start date. Prior procedures that are exclusionary should have both a start and end date.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PRSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The preferred method is to collect a complete Start Date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only) for procedures started a considerable amount of time prior to the start of study are acceptable.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication the procedure is ongoing when no end date is provided.
Question Text: Was the procedure ongoing (as of the [study-specific timepoint or period])?
Prompt: Ongoing (as of the [study-specific timepoint or period])
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the procedure has not ended at the time of data collection and the end date should be left blank.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as PRENRF or PRENRTPT. When populating PRENRF, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating PRENRTPT, if the value of PRONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When PRONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTM variable PRENRF should be populated. When PRONGO is used in conjunction with another time point, the SDTM variables PRENRTPT and PRENTPT should be used. Note: PRENRTPT must refer to a time point anchor described in PRENTPT.
Implementation Notes: Completed to indicate that the procedure has not stopped at the time point defined by the study. The purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring; this field provides further confirmation that the End Date was deliberately left blank. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions , and and SDTMIG for more information about mapping relative times.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end date of the procedure, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the procedure (end) date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the end date of the procedure using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If the procedure has not ended, leave this field blank and populate PRONGO as "Y".
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable PRENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The assumption is that sponsors should either have an end date or will indicate that the procedure was ongoing at the time of collection or at the end of the study. However, in cases where the end date can be determined from dates collected elsewhere in the CRF it is not necessary to include an end date in the CRF. For example, if the procedure is started and stopped within the same day, the end date will be the same as the start date.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The condition, disease, symptom, or disorder that the procedure was used to address or investigate (e.g., why the therapy was taken or administered, why the procedure was performed).
Question Text: For what indication was the [PRTRT] performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the reason the procedure was performed based on clinical investigator's evaluation. If performed to treat a condition, and a diagnosis was made, the indication should be the diagnosis. If performed to treat a condition, and no diagnosis was made, the indication should be the signs and symptoms. If taken as prophylaxis, report as "Prophylaxis for" and include a description of the condition(s).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This additional information is collected on the CRF when the sponsor wants to capture the reason(s) why a procedure was performed. This information can then be used as deemed appropriate for coding, analysis (e.g., in the classification of procedures), for reconciling the procedures performed on a subject with their provided medical history, and/or AEs/SAEs as part of the data clean-up and monitoring process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Identifier for the adverse event that is the indication for this procedure.
Question Text: What was the identifier for the adverse event(s) for which the procedure was performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier of the adverse event for which this procedure was performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the AE domain.
Implementation Notes: The intent is to establish a link between the adverse event and the procedure performed for the adverse event. PRAENO can be used to identify a relationship between records in the PR dataset and records in the AE dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on RELREC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Identifier for the medical history event that is the indication for this procedure.
Question Text: What was the identifier for the medical history event(s) for which the procedure was performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier of the medical history event for which this procedure was performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the MH domain.
Implementation Notes: The intent is to establish a link between the medical history condition and the procedure undergone for the medical history condition. PRMHNO can be used to identify a relationship between records in the PR dataset and records in the MH dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on RELREC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dose/amount administered during the procedure.
Question Text: What was the [dose/amount] of [PRTRT] (per administration/for the procedure)?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [dose/amount] of [PRTRT] per administered.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. Numeric values map to PRDOSE in SDTM. Non-numeric values (e.g., 200-400) map to PRDOSTXT in SDTM.
Implementation Notes: Defining this data collection field as a dose text field allows for flexibility in capturing dose entries as numbers, text or ranges. The data collected in this dose text-format field should be separated or mapped to either SDTMIG PRDOSE if numeric or PRDOSTXT if text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit for intended dose/amount for PRDOSE, PRDOSTOT, or PRDOSTXT.
Question Text: What was the unit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit for the amount of [PRTRT] performed or administered.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: When sponsors collect data for amount of PRTRT performed or administered, the unit should be collected as well (as applicable).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The number/amount of the procedure that was given/administered/taken during a specific interval.
Question Text: What was the frequency of [PRTRT]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record how often the procedure was performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This may be collected if it cannot be determined from other sources or if there are multiple options. Usually expressed as the number of procedures given per a specific interval.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The route of administration of the procedure.
Question Text: What was the route of administration of the procedure?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the route of administration for the procedure.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This additional information may be important to collect on the CRF when the sponsor would want to capture a procedure's route of administration for comparative analysis purposes.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A description of the anatomical location of an procedure (e.g., location of a biopsy).
Question Text: What was the anatomical location where the procedure was performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the body location where the procedure was performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location (e.g., Liver for the Biopsy). LAT, DIR, PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing side of the body for the procedure administration.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the administration?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location where the procedure was administered.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Further details the laterality of the location where the procedure was administered/taken. This may be preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the procedure?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the direction of the anatomical location where the procedure was administered.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).
Question Text: What was the portion or totality of the anatomical location that was treated?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the portion of the body location that was treated.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific portionality for the anatomical locations. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time.
Question Text: Was the subject fasting?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether the subject was fasting prior to the procedure being performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This information is collected when the procedure may be affected by whether the subject was fasting. This may not be relevant for all procedures.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The text description of the (intended) schedule or regimen for the procedure.
Question Text: What was the intended procedure regimen?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the intended regimen for the procedure to be performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The regimen information may further clarify the dose administration and dose frequency (e.g., TWO WEEKS ON, TWO WEEKS OFF). This may be prespecified or collected. The sponsor may wish to create a codelist to collect this data consistently.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the procedure dose/amount was adjusted.
Question Text: Was the procedure dose adjusted?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record if the procedure was adjusted from planned.
Mapping Instructions: When PRADJ is collected, does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED. When PRADJ is not collected, the sponsor may submit this variable as a SUPPQ.
Implementation Notes: Typically, the intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that the associate field on the CRF (PRADJ) was deliberately left blank. However, the sponsor may collect whether the procedure dose/amount was adjusted, without collecting the reason for the change.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Description of or explanation for why a procedure dose/amount was adjusted.
Question Text: What was the reason the procedure dose was adjusted?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record why the procedure dose was adjusted from planned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Captures the reason the PRTRT dose was changed or modified. The reason may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., adverse event, insufficient response) or entered as free text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication of whether the subject completed the intended regimen.
Question Text: Did the subject complete the full course of the [PRTRT]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record if the subject completed the intended regimen.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM= "PRTRTCMP" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Treatment Completed". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: Depending on how the PTTRT dose details are collected via the CRF/eCRF, it may be possible to derive those data if the regimen data are collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the procedure was interrupted.
Question Text: Was the procedure interrupted?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record if the procedure was interrupted.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: Provides a definitive response regarding any procedure interruption. The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring when the duration of the interruption is collected. In some situations, if the actual duration of the interruption is not collected, or not derived, this information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the intervention was interrupted.
Question Text: Why was the procedure interrupted?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the reason the procedure was interrupted.
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRITRPRS" and SUPPPR.QLABEL ="Reason Intervention Interrupted". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: This CDASH field is use to collected the reason why an intervention was interrupted. The sponsor may define controlled terminology.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The collected duration of the procedure interruption.
Question Text: What was the duration of the procedure interruption?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record how long the procedure was interrupted before it resumed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRITRPD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected procedure interruption duration and the duration unit components and create PRITRPD using ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: This field is used to collect the duration of procedure interruption. In some situations, the duration of the interruption may not be collected but calculated from the procedure start and end times recorded elsewhere in the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit for the collected duration of the procedure interruption.
Question Text: What was the interruption duration unit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unit for the duration of interruption of the procedure.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRITRPD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL= "Interruption Duration". Concatenate the collected procedure interruption duration and the duration unit components and create PRITRPD using ISO 8601 Period format. Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: The unit should be collected as a qualifier to the number for duration.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the lowest level term.
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRLLT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Lower Level Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for coding. Another dictionary can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the lowest level term.
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRLLTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="Lower Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the preferred term.
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR.QVAL dataset where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRPTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL= "Preferred Term Code Lower Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVsin SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the high level term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRHLT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This is not a data collection field that would appear on the CRF. Sponsors populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the high level term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR.QVAL dataset where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRHLTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Term Code". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This is not a data collection field that would appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the high level group term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM="PRHLTGT" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Group Term". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains. Sponsors should include an Origin column in the SUPPQ dataset to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Rationale for adding coding variables to CDASH is to provide a more complete data management package. This variable could be used in the PR domain for MedDRA coding. Other dictionaries can be used and the appropriate coding elements added, if appropriate, in the SUPPPR.QVAL dataset.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Procedure High Level Group Term Code
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the high level group term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: This information could be submitted in a SUPPPR dataset as the value of SUPPPR.QVAL where SUPPPR.QNAM= "PRHLTGTCD" and SUPPPR.QLABEL="High Level Group Term Code".
