DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the protocol deviation?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the deviation category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the DVCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory of the protocol deviation?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the deviation event subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. DVSCAT can only be used if there is an DVCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of DVCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether there were any protocol deviations.
Question Text: Were there any protocol deviations?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Enter Yes if a protocol deviation occurred and No if none occurred. Ensure that any adverse event which triggers a protocol deviation (e.g., concomitant medication use, newly discovered medical history) is noted in the respective CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The sponsor-defined standardized text for the name of the protocol deviation.
Question Text: What was the (standardized) protocol deviation (term/(code)?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record protocol deviations identified and/or select the appropriate code from the list of protocol deviation terms.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: DVTERM and DVDECOD may have the same value. If the CRF is collecting protocol deviations using a codelist of responses, then DVDECOD should be used to store the codelist response. Sponsors must use either DVDECOD or DVTERM on the CRF and, in some cases, both may be used. For example, if the CRF collects "Specify, Other" or similar additional free-text descriptions of codelist items, then DVTERM should be used to store the detailed descriptive text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The reported or prespecified name of the protocol deviation.
Question Text: What was the protocol deviation term?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the appropriate code from the list of protocol deviation terms.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: DVTERM and DVDECOD may have the same value. If the CRF is collecting protocol deviations using a free-text field, then DVTERM should be used to store the free-text response. Sponsors may use either DVDECOD or DVTERM on the CRF, but a value in DVTERM is required in the SDTM-based datasets.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start date of deviation, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the protocol deviation start date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the start date that the protocol deviation using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). This should be the start or occurrence of the protocol deviation, not the date it was discovered or reported.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable DVSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: This may be derived if not collected on a CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start time of the deviation, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the protocol deviation start time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If appropriate, record the start time (as complete as possible) of the protocol deviation in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss). This should be the start or occurrence of the protocol deviation, not the time it was discovered or reported.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable DVSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end date of the deviation, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the protocol deviation end date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the end date of the protocol deviation using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). This should be the date the protocol deviation stopped, not the date it was discovered or reported.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable DVENDTC in ISO 8601 format.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end time of the deviation, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the protocol deviation end time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If appropriate, record the end time (as complete as possible) of the protocol deviation in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss). This should be the time the protocol deviation stopped, not the time it was discovered or reported.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable DVENDTC in ISO 8601 format.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile data. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether there were any healthcare encounters.
Question Text: Were there any healthcare encounters?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the subject experienced any healthcare encounters. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the healthcare encounter?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor provides instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header. Examples include HOSPITALIZATION and OUTPATIENT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the HOCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the healthcare encounter?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor provides instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. HOSCAT can only be used if there is an HOCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of HOCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a health encounter occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific event is solicited.
Question Text: Did the subject have [prespecified healthcare encounter term]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if [specific healthcare encounter/event topic] has occurred/is occurring by checking Yes or No.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The CDASH variable HOOCCUR is used to report the occurrence of a prespecified healthcare encounter. HOOCCUR is not used if the healthcare encounters are collected on the CRF in a manner that requires a free-text response. The site should be able to indicate in a separate item (or system variable) that the question was not asked or answered.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that a specific event, or group of events, are specified on a CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: A hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM-based dataset creation, when the healthcare encounter is prespecified. Null for spontaneously reported events. If a study collects both prespecified healthcare encounters as well as free-text events, the value of HOPRESP should be "Y" for all prespecified events and null for events reported as free-text. HOPRESP is a permissible field in SDTM and may be omitted from the SDTM-based dataset if all events were collected as free text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available.
Question Text: What was the reason the data were not collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason why the subject's Healthcare Encounters experience was not assessed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor defined list (e.g., subject not asked) or entered as free text. When HOREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable HOSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, This is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile data. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The reported or prespecified name of the healthcare encounter.
Question Text: What was the healthcare encounter?; If [HODECOD], specify
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the healthcare encounter or if used with a HODECOD list, "Other" specify.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: If collected on the CRF, sponsors must use either HODECOD or HOTERM and in some cases, both may be used. If the CRF is collecting healthcare encounters using a standardized sponsor-defined code list (e.g., INPATIENT ER, ICU, SURGERY, GENERAL WARD, PROVIDER OFFICE - PRIVATE, PROVIDER OFFICE - HOSPITAL, GASTROENTEROLOGIST), then HODECOD may be used to store the code list response. If the CRF collects "Specify, Other" or similar additional free-text descriptions of code list items, then HOTERM may be used to store the detailed descriptive text. If HOTERM is entered only as free text, HODECOD would be populated through the sponsor's coding process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The sponsor-defined standardized text description of HOTERM or the modified topic variable (HOMODIFY), if applicable.
Question Text: What was the (standardized) healthcare encounter (term/code)?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the healthcare encounter.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: If collected on the CRF, sponsors must use either HODECOD or HOTERM and in some cases, both may be used. If the CRF is collecting healthcare encounters using a standardized sponsor defined code list (e.g., INPATIENT ER, ICU, SURGERY, GENERAL WARD, PROVIDER OFFICE-PRIVATE, PROVIDER OFFICE-HOSPITAL, GASTROENTEROLOGIST), then HODECOD may be used to store the code list response. If the CRF collects "Specify, Other" or similar additional free-text descriptions of code list items, then HOTERM may be used to store the detailed descriptive text. If HOTERM is entered only as free text, HODECOD would be populated through the sponsor's coding process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start date the healthcare encounter, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM] [start/admission] date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the start date of the healthcare encounter (e.g., date of admission) using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable HOSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The preferred method is to collect a complete start date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only, month and year only) may be acceptable.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start time of the healthcare encounter, (e.g., time of admission), represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM] [start/admission] time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the start time (as complete as possible ) of the healthcare encounter in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable HOSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end date of the healthcare encounter (e.g., date of discharge), represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM] [end/discharge] date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the end date of the healthcare encounter using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable HOENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The preferred method is to collect a complete end date. Partial dates (e.g., providing year only, month and year only) may be acceptable.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end time of the healthcare encounter (e.g., time of discharge), represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM] [end/discharge] time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the end time (as complete as possible) of the healthcare encounter in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable HOENDTC in ISO 8601 format.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Collected duration of the healthcare encounter.
Question Text: What was the duration of the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the duration of the healthcare encounter.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM-based dataset, concatenate the CDASH collected duration and collected duration unit and populate the SDTMIG variable HODUR in ISO 8601 Period format. Example: P1DT2H (for 1 day, 2 hours).
Implementation Notes: Collected duration of the healthcare encounter. Used only if collected on the CRF and not derived from the start and end date/times.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Unit of the collected duration of the healthcare encounter. Used only if duration was collected on the CRF.
Question Text: What was the duration unit of the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the appropriate duration unit of the healthcare encounter.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM-based dataset, concatenate the CDASH collected duration and collected duration unit and populate the SDTMIG variable HODUR in ISO 8601 Period format. Example: P1DT2H (for 1 day, 2 hours).
Implementation Notes: To ensure data quality, it is recommended that the appropriate duration unit(s) be preprinted on the (e)CRF. If only 1 unit is appropriate, no data entry would be required.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication that the encounter is ongoing when no end date is provided.
Question Text: Was the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM] ongoing(as of the[study-specific timepoint or period?
Prompt: Ongoing as of the[study-specific timepoint or period]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the healthcare encounter as ongoing ('Y') if it has not stopped at[at the timepoint defined by the study].
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable (e.g., HOENRF, HOENRTPT). When populating HOENRF, if the value of HOONGO is "Y", the values of "DURING", "AFTER", or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating HOENRTPT, if the value of HOONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When HOONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable HOENRF should be populated. When HOONGO is compared to any other time point, the SDTMIG variables HOENRTPT and HOENTPT should be used. \n Note: HOENRTPT must refer to a time-point anchor described in HOENTPT.
Implementation Notes: Completed to indicate that the healthcare encounter has not ended at the time of data collection. It is expected that every reported encounter has either an end date or the Ongoing field is populated, but not both. The purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring; this field provides further confirmation that End Date was deliberately left blank. Often used as a tick/checkbox. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and SDTMIG for more information.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Denotes the reason for the healthcare encounter.
Question Text: What was the reason for the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason for the subject's Healthcare Encounters.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPHO dataset as the value of SUPPHO_QVAL where SUPPHO.QNAM ="HOREAS" and SUPPHO.QLABEL="Healthcare Encounter Reason". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: To ensure data quality, it is recommended that the sponsor develop controlled terminology (e.g., LACK OF EFFICACY, ADVERSE EVENT, CHEMOTHERAPY, PHYSICAL THERAPY, INDICATION UNDER STUDY, NOT INDICATION UNDER STUDY). The sponsor may, however choose to collect this as free text or as a combination of preprinted options and free text in the form of "Specify, Other".

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Identifier for the adverse event that precipitated this encounter.
Question Text: What was the identifier for the adverse event(s), which precipitated the [healthcare encounter/HOTERM]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the adverse event that precipitated this encounter.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the Adverse Events domain.
Implementation Notes: The intent is to establish a link between the healthcare encounter record and the AE that was the primary cause of the encounter. HOAENO can be used in RELREC to identify a relationship between records in HO dataset and records in the AE dataset. Other identifiers needed to create RELREC (e.g., HOMHNO) can be created as needed. See SDTMIG for information on RELREC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM- based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.

Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.

Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether there was any medical history to report.
Question Text: Were any medical conditions or events reported?; Has the subject had any medical conditions or events?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the subject experienced any medical conditions or events. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the medical history?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor provides instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology (e.g., CARDIAC, GENERAL). This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header. This would be used when specific medical history (e.g., disease under study details) is captured, in addition to the general medical history.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the MHCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the medical history?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor provides instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. Typically would be used when specific medical history (e.g., disease diagnosis) is captured, in addition to the general medical history. MHSCAT can only be used if there is an MHCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of MHCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date on which the medical history was collected, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date the medical history was collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date on which the medical history was collected using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MHDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: This should be a complete date. The date of collection may be determined from a collected visit date.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile concomitant medications and/or procedure records with MH. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system. If CMMHNO or PRMHNO is used, this is the identifier to which CMMHNO or PRMHNO refers.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Specifies the aspect of the medical condition or event by which MHSTDTC and/or MHENDTC is defined.
Question Text: What was the medical history event date type?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: The instructions depend upon the format of the CRF. Sponsors may print these values on the CRF or use them as defaulted or hidden text.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The type of start/ and or end date (e.g., DIAGNOSIS, SYMPTOMS, RELAPSE, INFECTION). It is not related to the trial's condition. This date type cannot be a PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS, SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS because these terms do not define the date type.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Reported Term for the Medical History
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The reported or prespecified name of the medical condition or event.
Question Text: What is the medical condition or event term?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record all relevant medical conditions or events, as defined in the protocol. Record only 1 medical condition or event per line. Ensure that the medical conditions or events listed on the Medical History page do not meet any of the exclusion criteria.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsors should collect all relevant medical conditions or events, as defined in the protocol. It is a best practice for sponsors to collect all relevant history of surgeries or procedures using the associated diagnosis in the MH domain, while reporting relevant surgeries and procedures in the SDTM PR domain. Sponsors should provide instructions on how surgeries and procedures will be handled based on the protocol requirements. Information on specified surgeries or procedures should be collected in the PR domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a prespecified medical condition/event or a group of medical conditions/events occurred when information about the occurrence of a specific event is solicited.
Question Text: Did the subject have [prespecified medical condition/event/group of medical conditions]; Is the [prespecified medical occurring]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if [specific medical condition/event] has occurred/is occurring by checking Yes or No.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: MHOCCUR is used to report the occurrence of specified medical conditions or events. MHOCCUR is not used if the medical conditions or events are collected on the CRF in a manner that requires spontaneously free-text response. The site should be able to indicate that the question was not asked or answered.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that a specific event, or group of events, are prespecified on a CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: A hidden field on a CRF defaulted to "Y", or added during the SDTM-based dataset creation when the medical condition or event is prespecified. Null for spontaneously reported events. If a study collects both prespecified medical history and free-text events, the value of MHPRESP should be "Y" for all prespecified events and null for medical conditions or events reported as free text. MHPRESP is a permissible field in SDTM and may be omitted from the SDTM-based dataset if all events were collected as free text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the event occurred prior to study start.
Question Text: Did the medical condition or event start prior to [MHSTTPT]?; Did the medical condition or event start prior to study start?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Check if the medical condition or event started [before the study].
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as MHSTRF or MHSTRTPT. When populating MHSTRF, or MHSTRTPT, if the value of the CDASH field MHPRIOR is "Y" a value from the CDISC CT (STENRF) may be used. When MHPRIOR refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable MHSTRF should be populated. When MHPRIOR is compared to another time point, the SDTMIG variables MHSTRTPT and MHSTTPT should be used. Note: MHSTRTPT must refer to the time-point anchor described in MHSTTPT.
Implementation Notes: Sponsors may collect this information rather than start dates. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and SDTMIG v3.2 Section 4.1.4.7 for more information.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication the medical condition or event is ongoing when no end date is provided.
Question Text: Is the medical condition or event ongoing (as of the [study-specific timepoint or period])?
Prompt: Ongoing (as of the [study-specific timepoint or period])
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the medical condition or event as ongoing ("Y") if it has not ended at the time of data collection. If the medical condition or event is ongoing, the end date should be left blank.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into an SDTMIG relative timing variable such as MHENRF or MHENRTPT. When populating MHENRF, if the value of MHONGO is "Y", the value of "DURING", "AFTER" or "DURING/AFTER" may be used. When populating MHENRTPT, if the value of MHONGO is "Y", the value of "ONGOING" may be used. When MHONGO refers to the Study Reference Period (defined in DM.RFSTDTC to DM.RFENDTC) the SDTMIG variable MHENRF should be populated. When MHONGO is compared to another time point, the SDTMIG variables MHENRTPT and MHENTPT should be used. \n Note: MHENRTPT must refer to a time-point anchor described in MHENTPT.
Implementation Notes: Completed to indicate that the condition has not resolved at the time of data collection. It is expected that every reported condition has either an end date or the Ongoing field is populated, but not both. See Section 3.7, Mapping Relative Times from Collection to Submissions, and SDTMIG v3.2 Section 4.1.4.7 for more information.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Disease or Symptom Under Control
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication of whether the medical condition or event is under control at the time of data collection.
Question Text: Is the medical condition or event under control?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the most appropriate response.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPMH dataset as the value of SUPPMH.QVAL where SUPPMH.QNAM ="MHCTRL" and SUPPMH.LABEL="Medical Condition Under Control". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: MHCTRL is not defined in the SDTMIG MH domain. If collected, it should be submitted in the SUPPMH dataset. If MHCTRL is collected, the sponsor must provide information on the relative timeframe. Generally, MHDAT is collected or determined using the visit date of the collection to indicate this is the subject's status at the time of data collection.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The start date of medical history event or condition, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What [is/was] the [medical event or condition/category of the event] start date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the start date of the medical event or condition using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH START DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MHSTDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The sponsor may choose to capture a complete date or any variation thereof (e.g., month and year, year).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end date of medical history event or condition, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What[is/was] the[medical event or condition/category of the event] end date?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the end date of the medical event or condition using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MHENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The sponsor may choose to capture a complete date or any variation thereof (e.g., month and year, year).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A description of the anatomical location relevant for the medical condition or event.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location of the medical condition or event?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the anatomical location of the medical event or condition.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or preprinted when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location (e.g., ARM for skin rash). Could be a defaulted or hidden field on the CRF for prespecified [MHTERM/Event Topic]. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF. LAT, DIR, PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body relevant for the event.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the medical condition or event?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location of the medical event.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific side of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the medical condition or event?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the anatomical location of the medical event.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event Location Portion or Totality
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).
Question Text: What was the portion or totality of the anatomical location of the of the medical condition or event?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the portion or totality anatomical location of the medical event.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific portionality for the anatomical locations. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: If the value for MHTERM is modified to facilitate coding, then MHMODIFY will contain the modified text.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is not a data collection field that would appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary text description of MHTERM or the modified topic variable (MH MODIFY), if applicable.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to map the terms utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This is typically not a data collection field that will appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. Equivalent to the Preferred Term (PT in MedDRA).

CDASHIG Variable Label: Medical History Event Lowest Level Term
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the lowest level term.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event Lowest Level Term Code
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the lowest level term.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the preferred term.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Medical History Event High Level Term
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the high level term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event High Level Term Code
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the high level term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event High Level Group Term
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the high level group term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event High Level Group Term Code
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the high level group term for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event Primary System Organ Class
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived text description of the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Will be the same as MHBODSYS if the primary SOC was used for analysis.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MH Event Primary System Organ Class Code
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The dictionary-derived code for the primary system organ class (SOC).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The sponsor is expected to provide the dictionary name and version used to code utilizing the Define-XML external codelist attributes. Sponsors should include an Origin in the define metadata document to indicate that the data was "ASSIGNED".
Implementation Notes: This field does not typically appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. This is applicable to items using MedDRA coding. Will be the same as MHBDSYCD if the primary SOC was used for analysis.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using DD-MON-YYYY format.
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation, or specimen collection can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable CPDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the cell phenotype specimen was collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the cell phenotype at that visit, or the specimen collection date can be collected on the Cell Phenotype CRF using the date (CPDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the cell phenotype?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the cell phenotype test category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the CPCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory of the cell phenotype ?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the cell phenotype test subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. CPSCAT can only be used if there is a CPCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of CPCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned cell phenotype measurement, series of cell phenotype measurements, test, or observation was performed or specimens collected.
Question Text: Was the (cell phenotype) specimen collected?; Was the (cell phenotype) test performed?
Prompt: Cell Phenotype Test Performed; Specimen Collected
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not the cell phenotype specimen was collected or measurement performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable CPSTAT. If the CDASH variable CPPERF="N", the value of CPSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If CPPERF="Y", CPSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., CPCAT and CPSCAT, CPTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable CPTESTCD would be populated as CPALL and an appropriate test name (CPTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire cell phenotype category, or a specific cell phenotype test. This general prompt question is used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier (e.g., specimen identifier).
Question Text: What was the (cell phenotype specimen) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the cell phenotype specimen or accession number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to confirm that the appropriate data record is present in the electronic transfer. May be included for linking back to cell phenotype specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

CDASHIG Variable Label: Cell Phtype Test Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for the cell phenotype test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. SDTMIG time-point anchors CPTPTREF (text description) and CPRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables CPTPTNUM, CPELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of cell phenotype specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date of the cell phenotype specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) date when the cell phenotype specimen collection was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable CPDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of cell phenotype specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and, if so, a separate collection date field is not required. The SDTMIG CPDTC variable contains either a date/time when a cell phenotype specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a cell phenotype specimen is collected over time.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of cell phenotype specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the (start) time of the cell phenotype specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) time of collection (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable CPDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple cell phenotype specimens are collected on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis or a cell phenotype specimen is collected over an extended time period.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column .
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What is the subject identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be provided to the site using a prepopulated list in the system. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable VSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the CV measurements were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the observations at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the CV CRF using the Cardiovascular Assessments (CVDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned measurement, test, observation or specimen was performed/collected.
Question Text: Was cardiovascular assessment performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not a cardiovascular assessment was done.
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into the SDTM variable CVSTAT. If the CDASH variable CVPERF="N", the value of the SDTM variable CVSTAT is "NOT DONE". If CVPERF= "Y", CVSTAT is null. A combination of SDTM variables (e.g. CVCAT and CVSCAT, CVTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTM variable CVTESTCD would be populated with CVALL and an appropriate test name (CVTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This field is used to capture a response to whether or not a planned measurement, test or observation was performed. A negative response can be collected as "N" and mapped to the -STAT variable in SDTM as " NOT DONE".

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date the cardiovascular assessment was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g. DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date cardiovascular assessment was performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record date of assessment was performed using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable CVDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the CV assessment was performed can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the observations at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the CV CRF using the Date of Collection (CVDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of assessment, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g. hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the time of the Cardiovascular assessment performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record time of measurement (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable CVDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple assessments are done on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis

CDASHIG Variable Label: CV Assessment Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time points when assessments should be performed, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What is the planned time point for this Cardiovascular assessment performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for cardiovascular assessment, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTM time-point anchors CVTPTREF (text description) and CVRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables CVTPTNUM, CVELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then terms such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of assessment used to obtain the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What is the cardiovascular test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the cardiovascular test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column. The SDTM variable CVESTCD may be determined from the value collected in CVTEST using the Controlled Terminology List CVTESTCD. The SDTMIG variables CVTESTCD and CVTEST are required in SDTM.
Implementation Notes: The test name will usually be preprinted on the CRF, and not solicited as a question. If the form is laid out as a grid, then "Test" or "Test Name" can be included in the column heading. CVTEST is most useful as the PROMPT on the field in which the RESULT for that test is collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the Cardiovascular test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the Cardiovascular assessment category if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the CVCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the cardiovascular test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the Cardiovascular assessment subcategory if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined code list. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included in the column heading. CVSCAT can only be used if there is a CVCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of CVCAT.

CDASHIG Variable Label: CV Assessment Result in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the Cardiovascular test result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the result?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the original unit in which these data were collected, if not preprinted on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field. Should be included if applicable and not available elsewhere.

CDASHIG Variable Label: CV Assessment Test Result or Finding
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: Was the result (normal/abnormal/absent/present/ [sponsored defined response])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the overall assessment for [CVTEST].
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. The mapping instructions depend on the implementation; for example: \n 1. Where CVRES is to used collect Normal, Abnormal or similar type classifications (e.g., Absent/Present) with a description of the abnormal result using the CDASH field CVDESC. For SDTM submission datasets, If the CDASH field CVRES = "NORMAL", populate the SDTM variables CVORRES and CVSTRESC with the value of the CDASH field CVRES. If the CDASH field CVRES is "ABNORMAL", populate the SDTM variable REORRES with the CDASH field CVDESC. If the reported findings in CVDESC are coded using a dictionary, then the SDTM variable CVSTRESC is populated with the dictionary preferred term and CVMODIFY is populated with the modified text used for coding. If the reported findings in CVDESC are not coded, then the SDTM variable CVSTRESC is populated with the CDASH CVDESC field. The SDTM variable CVNRIND may be populated with "NORMAL" or "ABNORMAL" if appropriate. \n 2. Where CVRES is used to collect standardized values (e.g. a codelist) on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included, the CDASH field CVRESOTH can be used to collect free-text values for "Specify Other". When using this field, the "OTHER" value recorded in the CDASH field CVRES field is mapped to the SDTM variable CVSTRESC and the value in the CDASH field CVRESOTH is mapped to the SDTM variable REORR.
Implementation Notes: The CDASH field CVRES is used when the collected results are not mapped directly to the SDTM variable CVORRES and must be transformed. For example,CVRES is used to collect standardized values on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included and "Specify Other" is collected.CVORES is collected using Normal, Abnormal and a description of the abnormality is collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Text description of CV test findings.
Question Text: What was the description of the (abnormality/observed finding/[Sponsor-defined])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record all abnormal findings for the Cardiovascular test in the space provided.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into the SDTM variable CVORRES. If CVRES="Normal", populate CVORRES with the value of CVRES. If CVRES="Abnormal", populate CVORRES with the value of CVDESC.
Implementation Notes: CVRES and CVDESC are used when a question is asked to collect the finding result with a follow-up question for a description of the finding. See Section 8.3.1 General CDASH Assumptions for Findings Domains.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: This variable is used to indicate that data are not available, by having the site recording the value as "Not Done".
Question Text: Indicate if the [CVTEST] was not [answered/assessed/done/evaluated/performed].
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the cardiovascular test was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column. If collected, the Origin (a column in the Define-XML) ="CRF"; if populated from other sources such as free text or sponsor-defined listing for CVREASND, the Origin ="DERIVED".
Implementation Notes: Used only when the response value is collected as NOT DONE or NULL in lieu of or in addition to the CDASH CVPERF field. Typically a checkbox which indicates the test was NOT DONE. This field can be useful when multiple questions are asked to confirm that a blank result field is meant to be blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available.
Question Text: Was the was the reason that the cardiovascular (assessment/[CVTEST]) was not [collected / answered / done / assessed / evaluated]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason the measurement or test was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology may be used. The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When CVREASND is used, CVSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The position of the subject during a measurement or examination.
Question Text: What was the position of the subject during the assessment?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the position of subject at time of test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for Cardiovascular test, as specified in the protocol, were properly met. One common condition is the subject's position. If the protocol requires this type of information, then a CDASH variable [CVTESTCD]_CVPOS may be created for each CVTESTCD and added to the CRF, if needed.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Location used for the measurement.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location where the assessment was performed/measurement was taken?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select location on body where the measurement was performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or preprinted when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.LAT, DIR, and PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the [measurement/test/examination])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location of the cardiovascular test or measurement.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific side of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the cardiovascular test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the anatomical location of the cardiovascular test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The method of the test or examination.
Question Text: What was the method (used for the [measurement/test/examination])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method used for the cardiovascular test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: This information may be collected when more than 1 method is possible, and collecting the method used is necessary.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Question Text: Who was the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be a preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in CVEVAL.
Question Text: What is the identifier of the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unique identifier assigned to the person making the evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collect if multiple evaluators are used in the study (may be omitted if multiple evaluators are not used); values should follow controlled terminology.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included into the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies.
