See CDASHIG metadata tables for domain-specific TEST codelist names (e.g. EGTEST, FATEST).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A further description of OETESTCD and OETEST.
Question Text: What was the [measurement/test/examination] detail name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: It is recommended that the test detail name be preprinted on the CRF. If the form is laid out as a grid, then "Test" or "Test Name" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the [type/category] of the ophthalmic examination?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the OECAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the [subtype/subcategory] of the ophthalmic examination?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be a heading on the CRF or screen, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. OESCAT can only be used if there is a OECAT. Examples are provided in the CDASHIG metadata table and in the SDTMIG. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included in the column heading. OESCAT can only be used if there is a OECAT.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Result of Finding in Original Unit
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the ophthalmic examination test?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit (of the [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field. Should be included if applicable and not available elsewhere.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What [is/was] the [result/amount] (of the [measurement/test/examination])?; [Is/Was] the result [normal/abnormal/absent/present/ sponsored defined response]?
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. The mapping instructions depend on the implementation, for example: Where OERES Normal, Abnormal or other similar type classifications (e.g., absent/present) with a description of the abnormal result using the CDASH field OEDESC. For SDTM submission datasets, If the CDASH field OERES = "NORMAL", populate the SDTM variables OEORRES and OESTRESC with the value of the CDASH field OERES. If the CDASH field OERES is "ABNORMAL", populate the SDTM variable OEORRES with the CDASH field OEDESC. If the reported findings in OEDESC are coded using a dictionary, then the SDTM variable OESTRESC is populated with the dictionary preferred term and OEMODIFY is populated with the modified text used for coding. If the reported findings in OEDESC are not coded, then the SDTM variable OESTRESC is populated with the CDASH OEDESC field. The SDTM variable OENRIND may be populated with "NORMAL" or "ABNORMAL" if appropriate. Where OERES is used to collect standardized values (e.g., a codelist) on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included, the CDASH field OERESOTH can be used to collect free-text values for "Specify Other". When using this field, the "OTHER" value recorded in the CDASH field OERES field is mapped to the SDTM variable OESTRESC and the value in the CDASH field OERESOTH is mapped to the SDTM variable OEORRES. See the SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: The CDASH field OERES is used when the collected results are not mapped directly to the SDTM variable OEORRES and must be mapped, for example: OERES is used to collect standardized values on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included and "Specify Other" is collected. OERES is collected using Normal, Abnormal and a description of the abnormality is collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A free-text result which provides further information about the original received or collected result.
Question Text: If other is selected, [explain/specify/provide more detail].
Mapping Instructions: When using this CDASH field, the "OTHER" value collected in the CDASH field OERES is mapped to the SDTM variable OESTRESC and the value in the CDASH field OERESOTH is mapped to the SDTM variable OEORRES. See the SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: In a case where OERES is used to collect standardized values on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included, the CDASH field OERESOTH can be used to collect free-text values for "Specify Other".

CDASHIG Variable Label: Normal Range Lower Limit- Original Unit
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The lower end of normal range or reference range for continuous results stored in OEORRES.
Question Text: What was the lower limit of the reference range (for the [measurement/test/examination]?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: OEORNRLO should be populated only for continuous findings. The SDTM variable OESTNRC should be populated only for noncontinuous results. These data may be obtained from the lab or the electronic equipment. These data could be derived from a site- or lab-specific set of normal ranges stored in a look-up table.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Normal Range Upper Limit- Original Unit
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The upper end of normal range or reference range for continuous results stored in OEORRES.
Question Text: What was the upper limit of the reference range (for the [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: OEORNRHI should be populated only for continuous findings. The SDTM variable OESTNRC should be populated only for noncontinuous results. These data may be obtained from the lab or the electronic equipment. These data could be derived from a site- or lab-specific set of normal ranges stored in a look-up table.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Normal references ranges that are expressed as characters ("Negative to Trace") or ordinal (-1 to 1).
Question Text: What was the normal reference range (for this [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be populated for normal ranges that are reported as character in ordinal scale or if categorical ranges were supplied. These data may be obtained from the lab or the electronic equipment. These data could be derived from a site- or lab-specific set of normal ranges stored in a look-up table.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication or description about how the value compares to the normal range or reference range.
Question Text: How do the reported values compare within the [reference/normal/expected] range?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Reference ranges may be defined by OEORNRLO, OEORNRHI, OESTNRC, or other objective criteria. Reference Range Indicator (e.g., Y, N; HIGH, LOW; NORMAL, ABNORMAL) may be included if not derived or determined programmatically after data collection. Should not be used to indicate clinical significance.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indicator of the result of a finding or medical status per interpretation of test results.
Question Text: What is the the category for the reported values?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used to categorize the result of a finding or medical status per interpretation of test results (e.g., "POSITIVE", "NEGATIVE"). The variable OERESCAT is not meant to replace the use of OENRIND for cases where normal ranges are provided.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation of why the data are not available.
Question Text: What was the reason that the [ophthalmic examination finding] was not [collected/answered/done/assessed/evaluated]?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology may be used. The reason data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When OEREASND is used, OESTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The anatomical location of the subject, relevant to the collection of the measurement.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location of the ophthalmic examination?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: For the OE domain, this value is prepopulated as "EYE". It does not need to be preprinted on the CRF or collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Further detailing the laterality of the location of the OETEST within a given eye. It should never be used to designate "Right Eye" versus "Left Eye". OEFOCID is used to denote which eye is the focus of the observation. This may be preprinted or collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality (of the anatomical location of the [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Further detailing the directionality of the location of the OETEST (e.g., ANTERIOR, LOWER, PROXIMAL). This may be preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of CT on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).
Question Text: What was the portion or totality (of the anatomical location of the [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Further detailing the portion or totality of the location of the OETEST. This may be preprinted or collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The method of the test or examination.
Question Text: What was the method (used for the [measurement/test/examination])?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Question Text: Who was the evaluator?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be a preprinted, or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of CT on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in OEEVAL.
Question Text: What is the identifier of the evaluator?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the evaluation is considered, by an independent assessor, to be the accepted or final evaluation.
Question Text: Is this record considered to be the [accepted/final] evaluation?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used where more than 1 assessor provides an evaluation of a result or response. Typically a checkbox with the value of "Y" or "NULL", which indicates the evaluation was accepted.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The instance number of a test that is repeated within a given timeframe for the same test. The level of granularity can vary (e.g., within a time point, within a visit).
Question Text: What was the repetition number within the time point for this measurement?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: The repetition number of the test/measurement within the time point may be preprinted on the CRF (e.g., multiple measurements of blood pressure, multiple analyses of a sample.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column .
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be pre-printed on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be pre-populated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What is the subject identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be provided to the site using a pre-populated list in the system. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically pre-printed on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable VSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the RE measurements were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the observations at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the RE CRF using the Respiratory Assessments (REDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned measurement, test, observation or specimen was performed/collected.
Question Text: Was a respiratory assessment performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not a respiratory assessment was done.
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into the SDTM variable RESTAT. If the CDASH variable REPERF="N", the value of the SDTM variable RESTAT is "NOT DONE". If REPERF= "Y", RESTAT is null. A combination of SDTM variables (e.g., RECAT and RESCAT, RETPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTM variable RETESTCD would be populated with REALL and an appropriate test name (RETEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This field is used to capture a response to whether or not a planned measurement, test or observation was performed. A negative response can be collected as "N" and mapped to the -STAT variable in SDTM as " NOT DONE".

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date the respiratory measurement was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date the respiratory measurement was taken?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record date of measurements using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable REDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the RE measurements were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the observations at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the RE CRF using the Date of Collection (REDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of measurement, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the time of the respiratory system measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record time of measurement (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable REDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A single collection time (e.g., RETIM) may be collected for all the measurements when they are performed at the same time. The time of each measurement can also be collected using a CDASH variable [RETESTCD]_RETIM.

CDASHIG Variable Label: RE Assessment Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time points when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What is the planned time point for this respiratory assessment measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for respiratory assessment, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTM time-point anchors RETPTREF (text description) and RERFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables RETPTNUM, REELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be pre-printed on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then terms such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the test or examination used to obtain the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What is the respiratory test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the respiratory test, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column. The SDTM variable RETESTCD may be determined from the value collected in RETEST using the Controlled Terminology List RETESTCD. The SDTMIG variables RETESTCD and RETEST are required in SDTM.
Implementation Notes: The test name will usually be pre-printed on the CRF, and not solicited as a question. If the form is laid out as a grid, then "Test" or "Test Name" can be included in the column heading. RETEST is most useful as the PROMPT on the field in which the RESULT for that test is collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the respiratory test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the respiratory assessment category, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a pre-printed category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the RECAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the respiratory assessment?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the respiratory assessment subcategory, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a pre-printed category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included in the column heading. RESCAT can only be used if there is a RECAT, and it must be a subcategorization of RECAT.

CDASHIG Variable Label: RE Test Result in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the respiratory test result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the result?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the original unit in which these data were collected, if not pre-printed on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be pre-printed on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field. Should be included if applicable and not available elsewhere.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: Was the result (normal/abnormal/absent/present/ [sponsored defined response])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the overall assessment for [RETEST].
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. The mapping instructions depend on the implementation; for example: \n 1. Where RERES is to used collect Normal, Abnormal or similar type classifications (e.g., Absent/Present) with a description of the abnormal result using the CDASH field REDESC. For SDTM submission datasets, If the CDASH field RERES = "NORMAL", populate the SDTM variables REORRES and RESTRESC with the value of the CDASH field RERES. If the CDASH field RERES is "ABNORMAL", populate the SDTM variable REORRES with the CDASH field REDESC. If the reported findings in REDESC are coded using a dictionary, then the SDTM variable RESTRESC is populated with the dictionary preferred term and REMODIFY is populated with the modified text used for coding. If the reported findings in REDESC are not coded, then the SDTM variable RESTRESC is populated with the CDASH REDESC field. The SDTM variable RENRIND may be populated with "NORMAL" or "ABNORMAL" if appropriate. \n 2. Where RERES is used to collect standardized values (e.g. a codelist) on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included, the CDASH field RERESOTH can be used to collect free-text values for "Specify Other". When using this field, the "OTHER" value recorded in the CDASH field RERES field is mapped to the SDTM variable RESTRESC and the value in the CDASH field RERESOTH is mapped to the SDTM variable REORRES. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: The CDASH field RERES is used when the collected results are not mapped directly to the SDTM variable REORRES and must be transformed. For example,RERES is used to collect standardized values on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included and "Specify Other" is collected.REORES is collected using Normal, Abnormal and a description of the abnormality is collected.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Text description of respiratory test findings.
Question Text: What was the description of the (abnormality/observed finding/[Sponsor-defined])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record all abnormal findings for the respiratory test in the space provided.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. May be used to populate a value into the SDTM variable REORRES. If RERES="Normal", populate REORRES with the value of RERES. If RERES="Abnormal", populate REORRES with the value of REDESC.
Implementation Notes: RERES and REDESC are used when a question is asked to collect the finding result, with a follow-up question for a description of the finding. See CDASH General finding Assumptions

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A free-text result which provides further information about the original received or collected result.
Question Text: If other is selected, [explain/specify/provide more detail].
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide more detail for the "Other" result.
Mapping Instructions: When using this CDASH field, the "OTHER" value collected in the CDASH field RERES is mapped to the SDTM variable RESTRESC and the value in the CDASH field RERESOTH is mapped to the SDTM variable REORRES.
Implementation Notes: In cases where RERES is used to collect standardized values on the CRF and the value of "OTHER" is included, the CDASH field RERESOTH can be used to collect free-text values for "Specify Other".

CDASHIG Variable Label: RE Ref Range Lower Limit- Original Unit
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The lower end of normal range or reference range for continuous results stored in REORRES.
Question Text: What was the lower limit of the reference range?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the lower limit of the reference range of the respiratory test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: REORNRLO should be populated only for continuous findings. The SDTM variable RESTNRC should be populated only for noncontinuous results. These data may be obtained from the lab or the electronic equipment. These data could be derived from a site or lab specific set of normal ranges stored in a look-up table.

CDASHIG Variable Label: RE Ref Range Upper Limit- Original Unit
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The upper end of normal range or reference range for continuous results stored in REORRES.
Question Text: What was the upper limit of the reference range?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the upper limit of the reference range of the respiratory test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: REORNRHI should be populated only for continuous findings. The SDTM variable RESTNRC should be populated only for noncontinuous results. These data may be obtained from the lab or the electronic equipment. These data could be derived from a site or lab specific set of normal ranges stored in a look-up table.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication or description about how the value compares to the normal range or reference range.
Question Text: How do the reported values compare within the [reference/normal/expected] range?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record where the test result fell with respect to the reference range.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Reference ranges may be defined by REORNRLO, REORNRHI, RESTNRC or other objective criteria. Reference Range Indicator (e.g., Y, N; HIGH, LOW; NORMAL, ABNORMAL) may be included if not derived or determined programmatically after data collection. Should not be used to indicate clinical significance.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: This variable is used to indicate that data are not available, by having the site recording the value as "Not Done".
Question Text: Indicate if the [RETEST] was not [answered/assessed/done/evaluated/performed].
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the respiratory assessment or measurement was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column. If collected, the Origin (a column in the Define-XML) ="CRF"; if populated from other sources such as free text or sponsor-defined listing for REREASND, the Origin ="DERIVED".
Implementation Notes: Used only when the response value is collected as NOT DONE or NULL in lieu of or in addition to the CDASH REPERF field. Typically a checkbox which indicates the test was NOT DONE. This field can be useful when multiple questions are asked to confirm that a blank result field is meant to be blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available.
Question Text: Was the was the reason that the respiratory (assessment/[RETEST]) was not [collected / answered / done / assessed / evaluated]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason the measurement or test was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology may be used. The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined codelist (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When REREASND is used, RESTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The position of the subject during a measurement or examination.
Question Text: What was the position of the subject during the assessment?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the position of subject at time of test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for respiratory test, as specified in the protocol, were properly met. One common condition is the subject's position. If the protocol requires this type of information, then a CDASH variable [RETESTCD]_REPOS may be created for each RETESTCD and added to the CRF, if needed.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Location used for the measurement.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location where the measurement was taken?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select location on body where the measurement was performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or pre-printed when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.LAT, DIR, and PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the [measurement/test/examination])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location of the respiratory test or measurement.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be pre-printed or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific side of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the respiratory test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the anatomical location of the respiratory test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be pre-printed or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The method of the test or examination.
Question Text: What was the method (used for the [measurement/test/examination])?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method used for the respiratory test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: This information may be collected when more than 1 method is possible, and collecting the method used is necessary.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Question Text: Who was the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be a pre-printed or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in REEVAL.
Question Text: What is the identifier of the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unique identifier assigned to the person making the evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collect if multiple evaluators are used in the study (may be omitted if multiple evaluators are not used); values should follow controlled terminology.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the evaluation is considered, by an independent assessor, to be the accepted or final evaluation.
Question Text: Was this record considered to be the accepted evaluation?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not the evaluation is considered, by an independent assessor, to be the accepted or final evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Use where more than one assessor provides an evaluation of a result or response. Typically a checkbox with the value of "Y" or "NULL", which indicates the evaluation was accepted.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The instance number of a test that is repeated within a given timeframe for the same test. The level of granularity can vary (e.g., within a time point, within a visit).
Question Text: What was the repetition number within the time point for this measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the repetition number of the measurement within the time point.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: The repetition number of the test/measurement within the time point may be pre-printed on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the test results were clinically significant.
Question Text: Was this result clinically significant?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether respiratory test results were clinically significant.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTM variable listed in the SDTM Target column.
Implementation Notes: Could apply to specific measurements or to overall interpretation, as required by the protocol.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM- based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be pre-printed on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be pre-populated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically pre-printed on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable RPDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the reproductive system findings were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the reproductive system findings at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the RP CRF using the date (RPDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the reproductive system?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the reproductive system category, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a pre-printed category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the RPCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the reproductive system?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the reproductive system subcategory, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a pre-printed category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included in the column heading. RPSCAT can only be used if there is an RPCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of RPCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned measurement, series of measurements, test, or observation was performed.
Question Text: Was a reproductive system evaluation performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not a planned reproductive system evaluation was done.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable RPSTAT. If the CDASH field RPPERF="N", the value of RPSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If RPPERF="Y", RPSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., RPCAT and RPSCAT, RPTPT) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable RPTESTCD would be populated as RPALL and an appropriate test name (RPTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for a series of reproductive system evaluations, or a specific reproductive system test. This general prompt question is used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available.
Question Text: What was the reason the reproductive system test was not collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason the measurement or test was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When PCREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable PCSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: General prompt question regarding whether any reproductive system findings are available.
Question Text: Were there any reproductive system findings?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the there are reproductive system findings. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: The intent/purpose of collecting this field is to help with data cleaning and monitoring. It provides verification that all other fields on the CRF were deliberately left blank.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for pre-printed or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile data. May be used to record pre-printed number (e.g., line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name for reproductive system finding.
Question Text: What is the reproductive finding name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the name of the reproductive system finding, or record if not pre-printed on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable RPTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in RPTEST. The SDTMIG variables RPTESTCD and RPTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which test the result is for. It is recommended that test names be pre-printed on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included in the column heading.

CDASHIG Variable Label: RP Result or Finding in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the finding defined in reproductive system finding, as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result for the reproductive system question?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the reproductive system finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the result?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the original unit in which these data were collected, if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be pre-printed on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date on which the reproductive system result or finding was collected, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date the reproductive system question was collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date of collection using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable RPDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: This should be a complete date. The date of collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. If the date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM), concatenate the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populate the SDTMIG variable RSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: If the date the tests were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT), apply that date to all of the tests at that visit, or the collection date can be collected on the CRF using the date (RSDAT). In this domain, it may not be appropriate to use the visit date as RSDTC.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Category for Response or Clin Class
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the [category/ criteria] for the [disease response/clinical classification] or What is the [response/clinical classification] criteria?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is most commonly either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response is typically a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included in the column heading. There are separate codelists used for categorizing records about oncology response criteria (ONCRCAT) or other clinical classification (CRSCAT). Collect if multiple clinical classifications, or disease responses are active in a single study/database; otherwise, information should be distinguished somewhere on a form (e.g., table name, title, tab).

CDASHIG Variable Label: Subcategory for Response or Clin Class
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the RSCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory for the [disease response/clinical classification]?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. RSSCAT can only be used if there is an RSCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of RSCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned disease response or clinical classification assessment was performed.
Question Text: Was the [(disease) response/clinical classification] assessment performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not the [disease response/clinical classification] assessment was performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable RSSTAT. If RSPERF="N", the value of RSSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If RSPERF="Y", RSSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables ( e.g., RSCAT and RSSCAT, RSTPT) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable RSTESTCD would be populated as RSALL and an appropriate test name (RSTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: A Not Done checkbox, which indicates the test was "NOT DONE". Typically, there would be 1 check box for each measurement. This field can be useful to confirm that a blank result field is meant to be blank.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Reason Not Done
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation of why the data are not available.
Question Text: Why was the [disease response/clinical classification] assessment not performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If the response was not collected, indicate why.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason that data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., Not Imaged, Patient Refusal, Site Error) or entered as free text. When RSREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable RSSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Assessment Date
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of the Response or Clin Class was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date the response or clinical classification was performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date of measurements using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field does not map directly to an SDTM variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTM variable RSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the measurements were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the observations at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the RS CRF using the Date of Collection (RSDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the information.
Question Text: What was the role of the person performing the [disease response/clinical classification] assessment?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate who performed the assessment.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (assigned by a person or a group). RSEVAL is expected for oncology response criteria. It can be null when the investigator provides all the data in a study. It should contain no null values when data from 1 or more evaluator are used in a study.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Evaluator ID
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role.
Question Text: What is the evaluator identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Identify the evaluator providing this evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: When multiple assessors play the role identified in RSEVAL, values of RSEVALID will attribute a row of data to a particular assessor.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Link ID
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to link the disease response assessment to the related record in another domain which was used to determine the response result.
Question Text: What was the [Disease Response or Clinical Classification ]Link ID Identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected, record the unique [Disease Response or Clinical Classification] Link ID.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This variable is used to provide a unique code in order to link records across related CRFs (e.g., RS and TR) when appropriate. Sponsors develop their own conventions for populating RSLNKID.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Link Group
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping identifier used to link the disease response assessment to a group of related record in another domain which was used to determine the response result.
Question Text: What was the [Disease Response or Clinical Classification] Link Group Identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected, record the unique [Disease Response or Clinical Classification] Link Group ID.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This variable is used to provide a unique code in order to link a group of records across related CRFs (e.g., RS and TR) when appropriate. Sponsors develop their own conventions for populating RSLNKGRP.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Assessment Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the disease response or clinical classification used to obtain the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the [disease response/clinical classification] test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the RS test, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable RSTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in RSTEST. The SDTMIG variables RSTESTCD and RSTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which test the result is for. It is recommended that the test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included in the column heading.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Original Result
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the disease response or clinical classification as originally received, collected, or calculated.
Question Text: What was the [disease response/clinical classification]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the response classification.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Response or Clin Class Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the [disease response/clinical classification] unit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the original units in which these data were collected, if not preprinted on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field. Should be included if applicable and not available elsewhere.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).

Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable SCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the subject characteristics were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the subject characteristics at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the SC CRF using the date (SCDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the subject characteristics?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the subject characteristics category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the SCCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the subject characteristics?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the subject characteristics subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included in the column heading. SCSCAT can only be used if there is an SCCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of SCCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether any subject characteristics were collected.

Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if subject characteristics information was collected. If Yes, record the appropriate details.

Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.

Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile data. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g., line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

Implementation Notes: The date of collection can be determined from a collected date of the visit (VISDAT); in such cases, a date field is not required.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the subject characteristic of interest.

The SDTMIG variables SCTESTCD and SCTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which test the result is for. It is recommended that the test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included in the column header.

CDASHIG Variable Label: SC Result or Finding in Original Units

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to link related records across domains.

Implementation Notes: Because TRLNKGRP is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. This is typically used in oncology clincial trials. It is intended to group all the assessments at a evaluation time point represented in the TR domain with the associated response assessments represented in the RS domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.

This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. TRSCAT can only be used if there is a TRCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of TRCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation of why the data are not available.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the information.
Question Text: Who provided the information?; Who was the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the role of the person who provided the evaluation (e.g., INVESTIGATOR, ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE, VENDOR).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role.
Question Text: What was the identifier of the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the unique identifier assigned to the person making the evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collect if multiple evaluators are used in the study (may be omitted if multiple evaluators are not used); values should follow controlled terminology.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of the procedure used for tumor/lesion assessment, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date of the procedure used for [tumor/lesion] assessment?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date when the method used to assess the tumor/lesion occurred using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable TRDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: This is the date of the scan/image/physical exam used to evaluate the tumor/lesion. It is not the date the MRI or scan was read. This is typically not the visit date.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to link identified tumor/lesion to the assessment result.
Question Text: What was the [tumor/lesion] Identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected, record the unique identifier for this tumor/lesion.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This variable is used to provide a unique code for each identified tumor in order to link records across related CRFs (TU and TR) when appropriate. Sponsors develop their own conventions for populating --LNKID. Typically, the lesion/tumor is assigned the --LNKID at baseline when the tumor/lesion is identified, and this --LNKID is used at other visits to collect assessments on this tumor or lesion. \n Note: This variable may be collected using 1 CDASH variable name (e.g., TULNKID) and populated into TRLNKID when creating submisson datasets.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the [tumor/ lesion] (assessment) test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the tumor lesion assessment, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable TRTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in TRTEST. The SDTMIG variables TRTESTCD and TRTEST are required in SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which test the result is for. It is recommended that the test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included in the column heading.

CDASHIG Variable Label: TR Result or Finding in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the tumor/lesion assessment.
Question Text: What is the result for the [tumor/lesion assessment]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the tumor/lesion assessment result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. In addition to the SDTMIG variable TRORRES, create TRTESTCD from the CDASH variable name and determine the value of TRTEST from TRTESTCD. The CDASH prompt may also contain the TRTEST. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Result of the tumor/lesion assessment. Both quantitative and qualitative results may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the [result/measurement]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the original units in which these data were collected, if not preprinted on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Usually, the unit of the test is preprinted on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name or identifier of the vendor (e.g., laboratory) that provided the test results.
Question Text: What was the name of the vendor used?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the vendor providing the evaluation.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: It is recommended to collect on the CRF if vendor name was not collected at the site/study level or if multiple vendors are used by a site.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. If the date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM), then concatenate the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populate the SDTMIG variable TUDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: If the date the test was collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT), apply that date to all of the tests at that visit, or the collection date can be collected on the CRF using the date (TUDAT). In this domain, it may not be appropriate to use the visit date as TUDTC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the [tumor/lesion] identification?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the tumor identification category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This is most commonly either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the TUCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory for the [tumor/lesion] identification?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the tumor identification subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This is most commonly preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. TUSCAT can only be used if there is a TUCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of TUCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether any tumors were identified.
Question Text: Were any [target/non-target/new/sponsor-defined) [tumors/lesions] identified?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether [tumors/lesions] were identified. If Yes, include the appropriate details where indicated on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Not submitted.
Implementation Notes: This is intended to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing tumor/lesions evaluations are confirmed missing. The sponsor may decide to map "No" responses using the appropriate SDTMIG variables. Typically, this would use the SDTMIG variable TUOCCUR, with an appropriate TUTEST.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of the [examination/procedure] used for tumor/lesion identification, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
