Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the EGCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the ECG finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the ECG finding subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included as the column header EGSCAT can only be used if there is an EGCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of EGCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned measurement, series of measurements, test, or observation was performed.
Question Text: Was the ECG performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not ECG or specific ECG test was done.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable EGSTAT. If the CDASH field EGPERF="N", the value of EGSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If EGPERF="Y", EGSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables ( e.g., EGCAT and EGSCAT, EGTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable EGTESTCD would be populated as EGALL and an appropriate test name (EGTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire ECG, or a specific ECG test basis. General prompt question to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The incidence number of a test that is repeated within a given timeframe for the same test. The level of granularity can vary (e.g., within a timepoint, within a visit; multiple measurements of blood pressure, multiple analyses of a sample).
Question Text: What repetition of the ECG is this?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record which repetition of the ECG this is.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: If there are multiple ECGs, this is used to record in which order this ECG occurred.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Method of the test or examination.
Question Text: What was the method used for the ECG?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method used for the ECG.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for ECG as specified in the protocol were properly met. One possible condition is the method used to collect or calculate the ECG data. If the protocol requires this type of information, then this question may be included to confirm that the method used matches the protocol. The following are examples of when it is not necessary to collect these data on the CRF:Method of ECG is provided as part of the electronic data.Method of ECG is not pertinent to the protocol.The protocol specifies only 1 possible method for collecting ECG measurements and the sponsor does not feel there is significant risk of the sites performing the ECG using the incorrect method.

CDASHIG Variable Label: ECG Lead Location Used for Measurement
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The lead used for the measurement (e.g., "LEAD I", "LEAD II", "LEAD III", "LEAD rV2", "LEAD V1").
Question Text: Which lead location was used for this measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record which lead was used for this measurement.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is used when more specificity for the location is desired for the ECG data.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The position of the subject during the ECG measurement.
Question Text: What was the position of the subject during the ECG measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the position of the subject during the ECG.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for ECG as specified in the protocol were properly met. If the protocol requires this type of information, then this question may be included to confirm that the subject's position matches the protocol. The following are examples of when it is not necessary to collect these data on the CRF:Position of the subject is provided as part of the electronic data.Position of the subject is not pertinent to the protocol.The protocol specifies only 1 possible position and the sponsor does not feel there is significant risk of the sites performing the ECG with the subject in the wrong position.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date the ECG was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date of the ECG?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date ECG was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EGDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and if so, a separate assessment date field is not required.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the ECG measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time point labels for when the ECG test should be taken, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. SDTMIG time-point anchors EGTPTREF (text description) and EGRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables EGTPTNUM, EGELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Time of ECG, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the time the ECG was collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time the ECG was done (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EGDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple assessments are done on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the ECG test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the ECG measurement or finding, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the column with the heading SDTMIG Target. The SDTMIG variable EGTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in EGTEST. The SDTMIG variables EGTESTCD and EGTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which test the result is for. It is recommended that the test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included as the column heading.

CDASHIG Variable Label: ECG Result or Finding in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the ECG?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record test results, interpretations or findings.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the ECG results?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the original unit in which these data were collected, if not preprinted on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be included if quantitative results are recorded. Because units for quantitative ECG results are typically limited, units should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than having sites record the units. This item is not necessary for qualitative results.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the ECG results were clinically significant.
Question Text: Was the ECG clinically significant?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether ECG results were clinically significant.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Could apply to specific measurements or to overall interpretation.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started)
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable EGDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the ECG measurements were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the ECG measurements at that visit, or the collection date can be included on the ECG CRF using the date (EGDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics
Question Text: What was the category of the ECG finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the ECG finding category, if not on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the EGCAT values based on user-defined characteristics
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the ECG finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the ECG finding subcategory, if not on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included as the column heading. EGSCAT can only be used if there is an EGCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of EGCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned measurement, series of measurements, test, or observation was performed
Question Text: Was the ECG performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not an ECG or specific ECG test was done.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable EGSTAT. If the CDASH field EGPERF="N", the value of EGSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If EGPERF="Y", EGSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., EGCAT and EGSCAT, EGTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable EGTESTCD would be populated as EGALL and an appropriate test name (EGTEST) provided. See the SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire ECG, or a specific ECG test basis. General prompt question to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The incidence number of a test that is repeated within a given timeframe for the same test. The level of granularity can vary (e.g., within a timepoint, within a visit; multiple measurements of blood pressure, multiple analyses of a sample).
Question Text: Which repetition of the ECG is this?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record which repetition of the ECG this is.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: If there are multiple ECGs, this is used to record in which order this ECG occurred.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier of the ECG (e.g., waveform number)
Question Text: What was the (ECG) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to confirm that the appropriate data record is present in the electronic transfer if this reference ID happens to be available to the site at the time of collection. Examples: Universally unique identifier (UUID) for external waveform file, session number automatically generated by electronic equipment. This can also be used to link.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Method of the test or examination
Question Text: What was the method used for the ECG?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method used for the ECG.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for ECG as specified in the protocol were properly met. If the protocol requires this type of information, then this question may be included to confirm that the method used matches the protocol. The following are examples of when it is not necessary to collect these data on the CRF:Method of ECG is provided as part of the electronic data.Method of ECG is not pertinent to the protocol.The protocol specifies only 1 possible method for collecting ECG measurements and the sponsor does not feel there is significant risk of the sites performing the ECG using the incorrect method.

CDASHIG Variable Label: ECG Lead Location Used for Measurement
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The lead used for the measurement (e.g., "LEAD I", "LEAD II", "LEAD III", "LEAD rV2", "LEAD V1")
Question Text: Which lead location was used for this measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record which lead was used for this measurement.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is used when more specificity for the location is desired for the ECG data.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The position of the subject during the ECG measurement
Question Text: What was the position of the subject during the ECG measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the position of the subject during the ECG.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether conditions for ECG as specified in the protocol were properly met. If the protocol requires this type of information, then this question may be included to confirm that the subject's position matches the protocol. The following are examples of when it is not necessary to collect these data on the CRF:Position of the subject is provided as part of the electronic data.Position of the subject is not pertinent to the protocol.The protocol specifies only 1 possible position and the sponsor does not feel there is significant risk of the sites performing the ECG with the subject in the wrong position.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date the ECG was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY)
Question Text: What was the date of the ECG?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date ECG was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EGDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and if so, a separate assessment date field is not required.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken as defined in the protocol
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the ECG measurement?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time point labels for when the ECG test should be taken, if not on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. SDTMIG time point anchors EGTPTREF (text description) and EGRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables EGTPTNUM, EGELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Time of ECG, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss)
Question Text: What was the time the ECG was collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time the ECG was done (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable EGDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple assessments are done on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the evaluation
Question Text: Who provided the information?; Who was the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the role of the person who provided the evaluation (e.g., INVESTIGATOR, ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE, VENDOR).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Overall interpretation of the result of the measurement or finding
Question Text: What was the interpretation of the ECG?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record overall interpretations of the ECG.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTM variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, the recorded interpretation is populated into the SDTMIG variable EGORRES where EGTEST= "Interpretation", and EGTESTCD="INTP".
Implementation Notes: The overall interpretation of an ECG is mapped into the appropriate SDTM test and result variables. See the SDTMIG EG Domain for details.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the ECG results were clinically significant
Question Text: Was the ECG clinically significant?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether ECG results were clinically significant.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Could apply to specific measurements or to overall interpretation. In this scenario, clinical significance could be provided by the investigator.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Identifier for the medical history event that was reported as a clinically significant ECG finding
Question Text: What was the identifier for the medical history event that was reported as a clinically significant ECG finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the medical history event that was reported as a clinically significant ECG finding.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the MH domain.
Implementation Notes: Intent is to establish a link between the clinically significant ECG finding and the medical history event that was reported. EGMHNO can be used in RELREC to identify a relationship between records in EG dataset and records in the MH dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on creating RELREC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Identifier for the adverse event that was reported as a clinically significant ECG finding
Question Text: What was the identifier for the adverse event(s) that was reported as a clinically significant ECG finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the adverse event that was the reported as a clinically significant ECG finding.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission datasets, may be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in the AE domain.
Implementation Notes: Intent is to establish a link between the clinically significant ECG finding and the AE that was reported. EGAENO can be used to identify a relationship between records in EG dataset and records in the AE dataset. See the SDTMIG for information on creating RELREC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using DD-MON-YYYY format.
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation, or specimen collection can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable GFDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the genomic specimen was collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the genomic tests at that visit, or the specimen collection date can be collected on the Genomic Finding CRF using the date (GFDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the genomic test category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the GFCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the genomic test subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. GFSCAT can only be used if there is a GFCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of GFCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned genomic measurement, series of genomic measurements, test, or observation was performed or specimens collected.
Question Text: Was the (genomic) specimen collected?; Was the (genomic) test performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not the genomic specimen was collected or measurement performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable GFSTAT. If the CDASH variable GFPERF="N", the value of GFSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If GFPERF="Y", GFSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., GFCAT and GFSCAT, GFTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable GFTESTCD would be populated as GFALL and an appropriate test name (GFTEST) provided. See the SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire genomic category, or a specific genomic test. This general prompt question is used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier (e.g., specimen identifier).
Question Text: What was the (genomic specimen) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the genomic specimen or accession number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to confirm that the appropriate data record is present in the electronic transfer. May be included for linking back to genomic specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

CDASHIG Variable Label: Genomic Test Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for the genomic test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. SDTMIG time-point anchors GFTPTREF (text description) and GFRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables GFTPTNUM, GFELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of genomic specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date of the genomic specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) date when the genomic specimen collection was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable GFDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of genomic specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and, if so, a separate collection date field is not required. The SDTMIG GFDTC variable contains either a date/time when a genomic specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a genomic specimen is collected over time.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of genomic specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the (start) time of the genomic specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) time of collection (as complete as possible).

Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple genomic specimens are collected on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis or a genomic specimen is collected over an extended time period.

Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.

Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation, or specimen collection can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable GFDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the genomic specimen was collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the genomic tests at that visit, or the specimen collection date can be collected on the Genomic Finding CRF using the date (GFDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the category of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the genomic test category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the GFCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What is the subcategory of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the genomic test subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included as the column heading. GFSCAT can only be used if there is an GFCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of GFCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned genomic measurement, series of genomic measurements, test, or observation was performed or specimens collected.
Question Text: Was the (genomic) specimen collected?; Was the (genomic) test performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not the genomic specimen was collected or measurement performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable GFSTAT. If the CDASH variable GFPERF="N", the value of GFSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If GFPERF="Y", GFSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., GFCAT and GFSCAT, GFTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable GFTESTCD would be populated as GFALL and an appropriate test name (GFTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire genomic category, or a specific genomic test. This general prompt question is used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name or identifier of the vendor (e.g., laboratory) that provided the genomic test results.
Question Text: What was the name of the laboratory used?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the laboratory name.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Recommended to collect on the CRF if lab name was not collected at the site/study level or if multiple labs are used by a site.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the genomic test used to obtain the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the name of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the genomic test, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable GFTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in GFTEST. The SDTMIG variables GFTESTCD and GFTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which genomic test the result is for. It is recommended that the genomic test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field that requires the site to enter text. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Genomic Test" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Detail of the genomic test used to obtain the \n measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the genomic test detail?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the detail of the genomic test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Provides additional details for the genomic test. \n It is recommended that the test detail be preprinted on the CRF. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Genomic Test Detail" can be included as the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Method of the genomic test.
Question Text: What was the method used for the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method of the genomic test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This information may be collected when more than 1 method of genomic test is possible, and collecting the method used is necessary.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Genomic Test Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for the genomic test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. SDTMIG time-point anchors GFTPTREF (text description) and GFRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables GFTPTNUM, GFELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of genomic specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date of the genomic specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) date when the genomic specimen collection was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable GFDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of genomic specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and, if so, a separate collection date field is not required. The SDTMIG GFDTC variable contains either a date/time when a genomic specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a genomic specimen is collected over time.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of genomic specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the (start) time of the genomic specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) time of collection (as complete as possible)
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable GFDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple genomic specimens are collected on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis or a genomic specimen is collected over an extended time period.

CDASHIG Variable Label: GF Result or Finding in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the genomic test as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the genomic test result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

CDASHIG Variable Label: Genomic Result or Finding Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the genomic test result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the genomic test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the original unit in which these data were collected, if not preprinted on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field. Should be included if applicable and not available elsewhere. For some genomic tests the units may not be applicable.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed in the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using DD-MON-YYYY format.
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation, or specimen collection can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable LBDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the laboratory specimens were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the laboratory tests at that visit, or the specimen collection date can be collected on the Laboratory CRF using the date (LBDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned lab measurement, series of lab measurements, tests, observations was performed or specimens collected.
Question Text: Was the sample collected?; Was the lab performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not lab specimen was collected or measurement performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable LBSTAT. If the CDASH variable LBPERF = "N", the value of LBSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If LBPERF = "Y", LBSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables ( e.g., LBCAT and LBSCAT, LBTPT) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable LBTESTCD would be populated as LBALL and an appropriate test name (LBTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire lab panel, or a specific lab test. General prompt question to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date of the lab specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) date when specimen collection was done using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable LBDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and, if so, a separate assessment date field is not required. The SDTMIG LBDTC variable contains either a date/time when a specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a specimen is collected over time.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the (start) time of the lab specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) time of collection (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable LBDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple assessments are done on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis or a specimen is collected over an extended time period.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the name of the lab panel?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the lab test category, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included in the column heading. Laboratory tests have commonly recognized categories and subcategories that should be used whenever appropriate. LBCAT and or LBSCAT should be included if lab status (NOT DONE) is collected for each lab category/subcategory (e.g., HEMATOLOGY, CHEMISTRY, URINALYSIS).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the LBCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the name of the lab sub-panel?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the lab test subcategory, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology (e.g. electrolytes, liver function). This would most commonly be preprinted on the CRF or screen and prepopulated in the data management system. This is not typically a question to which the site would provide an answer. Laboratory tests have commonly recognized categories and subcategories that should be used whenever appropriate. LBSCAT can only be used if there is an LBCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of LBCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The type of sample material taken from a biological entity.
Question Text: What is the specimen material type?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen material type.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The type of specimen used for a measure. Should be collected if not available elsewhere, or if required to differentiate multiple specimens.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time point when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the lab?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time point labels for the lab test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. SDTMIG time-point anchors LBTPTREF (text description) and LBRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables LBTPTNUM, LBELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication whether the testing conditions defined in the protocol were met (e.g., low-fat diet).
Question Text: Were the protocol-defined testing conditions met?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether protocol defined testing conditions were met.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPLB dataset as the value of SUPPLB.QVAL where SUPPLB.QNAM ="LBCOND" and SUPPLB.LABEL="Test Condition Met". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables (NSVs) in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: This information is collected when the laboratory test results may be affected by whether conditions for testing were properly met. The specific testing conditions required should be preprinted on the CRF. This may not be relevant for all tests.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time.
Question Text: Was the subject fasting?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether the subject was fasting prior to the test being performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether the subject was fasting. This may not be relevant for all tests.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier (e.g., specimen identifier).
Question Text: What was the (laboratory test) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen or accession number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to confirm that the appropriate data record is present in the electronic transfer. May be included for linking back to specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.

Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.

For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

Question Text: What was the result of the lab test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the laboratory test result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Optional if already provided from central lab.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
