Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire panel. General prompt question to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing. For the SDTM submission dataset, the SDTMIG variable MSSTAT is populated using the CDASH field MSPERF. The question text used might be reflected in the reason not done (MSREASND).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier, such as specimen identifier.
Question Text: What was the (microbiology susceptibility test) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen [accession/reference] number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to confirm that the appropriate data record is present in the electronic transfer. May be included for linking back to specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date of the (microbiology) specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) date when specimen collection occurred using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and if so, a separate assessment date field is not required, The SDTMIG MSDTC variable contains either a date/time when a specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a specimen is collected over time.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the (start) time of the (microbiology) specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) time of susceptibility test (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple assessments are done on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the microbiology susceptibility test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the microbiology susceptibility category, or record if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the MSCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the microbiology susceptibility finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the microbiology susceptibility subcategory, or record if not pre-preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included as the column header. MSSCAT can only be used if there is an MSCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of MSCAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Defines the type of specimen used for a measurement.
Question Text: What is the specimen material type?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen material type.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The type of specimen used for a measure. Should be collected if not available elsewhere, or if required to differentiate multiple specimens.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Description of the condition of the specimen.
Question Text: What was the condition of the specimen?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the condition of the specimen.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be collected using free or standardized text. This can be used when results may be affected by whether conditions for specimen were properly met.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A description of the anatomical location of the subject relevant to the collection of specimen.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location where the specimen was collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the anatomical location of specimen collection.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or preprinted when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF. LAT, DIR, and PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location of the specimen collection.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific side of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the anatomical location of the specimen collection.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The identifier for a non-host organism, which should only be used when the organism is the subject of the test.
Question Text: What was the non-host organism ID?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the non-host organism that is the subject of the test.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined identifier for a non-host organism, which should only be used when the organism is the subject of the test

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation or specimen collection can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable MIDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the microbiology specimens were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the microbiology susceptibility findings at that visit, or the specimen collection date can be included on the MS CRF using the date (MSDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned measurement or series of measurements, tests, or observations was performed, or specimen was collected
Question Text: Was the [microbiology susceptibility test] performed? Was the [microbiology susceptibility specimen/sample] collected?
Prompt: [Microbiology Susceptibility Test] Performed; [Microbiology Susceptibility Specimen/Sample] Collected;
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether or not microbiology susceptibility test was performed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTM variable MSSTAT. If MSPERF = "N", the value of MSSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If MSPERF = "Y", MSSTAT should be null. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., MSCAT and MSSCAT, MSTPT ) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable MSTESTCD would be populated as MSALL and an appropriate test name (MSTEST) provided. See the SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This may be implemented for an entire panel. General prompt question to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier, such as specimen identifier.
Question Text: What was the (microbiology susceptibility test) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen [accession/reference] number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to reconcile CRF data. May be included for linking back to specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for preprinted or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile data. May be used to record preprinted number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A group identifier used to link together a block of related records within a subject in a domain.
Question Text: What [is/was] the [test/procedure/observation] group identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each microbiology susceptibility test or result record has a unique identifier that will group records within a subject within the domain.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used to link together a block of related records within a subject. Should not be used to link detection records in MB to the associated susceptibility results in the MS domain. NHOID should be used to identify the non-host organism.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An identifier used to link related records across domains.
Question Text: What [is/was] the [test/procedure/observation] link identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each microbiology susceptibility result has an identifier that will link records across domains.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This may be a one-to- one or a one-to-many relationship. For example, a single microbiology specimen or result may have multiple measurements/assessments performed (e.g., susceptibility testing).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of specimen collection ,represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the (start) date of the (microbiology) specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) date of specimen collection using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT) and, if so, a separate assessment date field is not required.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the (start) time of the the (microbiology) collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the (start) time of collection (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable MSDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: May be required when multiple assessments are done on 1 day or when the timing in relationship to study treatment is required for analysis.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the microbiology susceptibility finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the microscopic finding category, or record if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading, or a preprinted category value on the CRF and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Category" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the MSCAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the subcategory of the microbiology susceptibility finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the microscopic finding subcategory, or record if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. This would most commonly be either a heading or a preprinted category value on the CRF, and not a question to which the site would provide an answer. If a question is asked, the response would typically be a sponsor-defined codelist. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Subcategory" can be included as the column header. MSSCAT can only be used if there is an MSCAT, and it must be a subcategorization of MSCAT.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MS Organism Test or Finding Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the microbiology susceptibility test or examination used to obtain the measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the microbiology susceptibility test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the type or name of the microbiology susceptibility test or examination, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable MSTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in MSTEST. Both MSTESTCD and MSTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Required to identify which test the result is for. It is recommended that the test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Detail of the microbiology susceptibility test used to obtain the measurement or finding. Helps to establish a unque record.
Question Text: What was the microbiology susceptibility test detail?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the detail of the microbiology susceptibility test, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Provides additional details for the microbiology susceptibility test if necessary to define a unique record. It is recommended that the test detail be preprinted on the CRF. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test Detail" can be included as the column header.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of the agent for which resistance is tested.
Question Text: What was the name of the agent for which resistance is being tested?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the agent for which resistance is being tested.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the agent for which resistance is tested. The agent specified may be based on genetic markers or direct phenotypic drug sensitivity testing.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The concentration of the agent for which resistance is tested.
Question Text: What was the concentration of the agent?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the concentration of the agent.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Numeric concentration of agent listed in MSAGENT

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The concentration unit of the agent for which resistance is tested.
Question Text: What was the agent concentration unit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the concentration unit of the agent.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Units for value of the agent concentration listed in MSCONC

CDASHIG Variable Label: MS Result or Finding in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record test result, interpretation, or finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the result?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the original unit in which these data were collected, or record if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field. Should be included if applicable and not available elsewhere. For some tests, the units may not be applicable (e.g., where MSTEST requires simply a qualitative result).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication whether the test results were clinically significant.
Question Text: Was the result clinically significant?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether the results were clinically significant.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPMS dataset as the value of SUPPMS.QVAL where SUPPMS.QNAM="MSCLSIG" and SUPPMS.QLABEL="Clinically Significant". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Used to categorize the result of a finding.
Question Text: What was the result category?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the category of the test results.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used to categorize the results of a finding (e.g., "SUSCEPTIBLE", "RESISTANT")

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name or identifier of the vendor (e.g., laboratory) that provided the test results.
Question Text: What was the name of the vendor used?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the laboratory name.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Recommended to collect on the CRF if lab name was not collected at the site/study level, or if multiple labs are used by a site

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Defines the type of specimen used for a measurement.
Question Text: What is the specimen material type?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen material type.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The type of specimen used for a measure. Should be collected if not available elsewhere, or if required to differentiate multiple specimens.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Describes the condition of the specimen.
Question Text: What was the condition of the specimen?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the condition of the specimen.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be collected using free or standardized text. This can be used when results may be affected by whether conditions for specimen were properly met.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A description of the anatomical location of the subject, relevant to the collection of specimen.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location where the specimen was collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record or select the anatomical location of specimen collection.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or preprinted when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF. LAT, DIR, and PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location of the specimen collection.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific side of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the anatomical location of the specimen collection.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be preprinted or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

CDASHIG Variable Label: MS Method of Test or Examination
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Method of the test or examination.
Question Text: What was the method used for the test or examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method of test or examination.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This information may be collected when more than one method is possible, and collecting the method used is necessary. This could include technique or type of staining used for the slides.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person providing the evaluation.
Question Text: Who was the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the role of the person who provided the evaluation (e.g., INVESTIGATOR, ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE, VENDOR).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be preprinted or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable PCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the PK samples were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the PK samples at that visit, or the collection date can be collected on the PK CRF using the date (PCDAT) field.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether PK samples were collected.
Question Text: Were PK samples collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Check "No" if none of the samples were collected.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable PCSTAT. If PCPERF="N", the value of PCSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If PCPERF="Y", PCSTAT should be null. PCTEST and PCTESTCD must reflect what tests were not done. A combination of SDTMIG variables ( e.g., PCCAT and PCSCAT, PCTPT) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable PCTESTCD would be populated as PCALL and an appropriate test name (PCTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: General prompt question to be used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing. This may be implemented at form level or sample level. These may be all samples of a particular type or all samples taken for some purpose and may need to be identified by the organization of the data on the form. Each sample collected could result in 1 or more tests performed, so there can be a one-to-one or one-to-many relationship between samples and tests/results.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: This variable used to indicate that data are not available, by having the site record the value as "Not Done".
Question Text: Record "Not Done" if the PK sample was not collected.
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate if the specimen was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: A Not Done checkbox, which indicates the test was "NOT DONE". Typically, there would be 1 checkbox for each measurement. This field can be useful on individual sample collections to confirm that a blank result field is meant to be blank.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available.
Question Text: What was the reason the PK sample was not collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason why a PK sample was not collected.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When PCREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable PCSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of PK sample collection or the start date of PK sample collection over a period of time (protocol-defined time-point range), represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date of the PK sample collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date when PK sample collection occurred using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If left blank, "PCDATFL" for this specimen must be populated (or "PCPERF" must be flagged to indicate this sample was not collected).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The date of collection may be determined from the date of visit (VISDAT); if so, a separate assessment date field is not required. The SDTMIG PCDTC variable contains either a date/time when a specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a specimen is collected over time.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Flag indicating that the PK date (or start date) is the same as the previous specimen collection date (or start date).
Question Text: Was the specimen/sample collected on the same date as the [last/previous specimen/sample] [collected/collection ended]?
Prompt: Same as Previous (Specimen/Sample Collection End) Date
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select when the date of this specimen collection is the same as the date of the previous specimen collected. If left blank, "PCDAT" for this specimen must be populated. (or "PCPERF" must be flagged to indicate this sample was not collected)
Mapping Instructions: Does not map to an SDTMIG variable. The SDTM annotated CRF indicates that this field is NOT SUBMITTED.
Implementation Notes: When a series of specimens are collected on a single form, this field is tied to the collection date to allow for the flag to be used as a surrogate for the date field. Its selection means that the date of this specimen is the same as the date of the last specimen collected (in the series). This variable may be used when collecting PK data and re-entering dates is more cumbersome than selecting the checkbox.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of PK sample collection or start time for a specimen collected over a period of time (protocol-defined time-point range), represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the time of the PK sample collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record time of collection (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete time is expected. The SDTMIG PCDTC variable contains either a date/time, when a specimen is collected at a point in time, or the start date/time, when a specimen is collected over time.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
CDASHIG Variable Label: PK Sampling Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time points when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol.
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the PK sample collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for the PK sample collection, if not preprinted on the CRF. Note: Planned time points are often described as relative to the dosing of the study drug.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTMIG time-point anchors PCTPTREF (text description) and PCRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables PCTPTNUM, PCELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then terms such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time.
Question Text: Was the subject fasting?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether the subject was fasting prior to the test being performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether the subject was fasting. Some study treatments may have a food effect, and it is important to know whether the dose was taken after the subject had fasted.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication of whether the testing conditions defined in the protocol were met (e.g., low-fat diet).
Question Text: Were the protocol-defined testing conditions met?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether protocol-defined testing conditions were met.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPC dataset as the value of SUPPPC.QVAL where SUPPPC.QNAM ="PCCOND" and SUPP.PCLABEL= "Test Condition Met". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of non-standard variables in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: This information is collected when the test results may be affected by whether conditions for testing were properly met. The specific testing conditions required should be preprinted on the CRF (e.g., "Did subject meet diet requirements?"). This may not be relevant for all tests. Examples of conditions imposed may include calorie fast, fluid fast, high-fat meal, low-fat meal, and exercise.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier (e.g., specimen identifier).
Question Text: What was the (PK) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen or accession number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to reconcile CRF data. May be included for linking back to specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The type of specimen used for a PK sample.
Question Text: What was the specimen (material) type?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen material type, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The type of specimen used for a measure. Should be collected if not available elsewhere, or if required to differentiate multiple specimens.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the analyte or specimen characteristics used to obtain the PK measurement or finding.
Question Text: What was the test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the measurement or finding, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable PCTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in PCTEST. The SDTMIG variables PCTESTCD and PCTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC Controlled Terminology for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Sponsors typically collect tests related to the specimen characteristics on the CRF (e.g., volume, pH). Results for tests on an analyte (e.g., concentration) would typically be populated when creating SDTM-based datasets. If the analyte test results are collected on the CRF, the test would be the analyte name. It is recommended that the test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included in the column heading.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
CDASHIG Variable Label: PK Sampling Result in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the result of the test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the test result, interpretation, or finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection at Fixed Time Points
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected.
Question Text: What was the unit of the result?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the original unit in which these data were collected, or record if not preprinted on CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Should be preprinted on the CRF with the associated test when possible, rather than collected in a free-text field.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study
Question Text: What is the subject identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically preprinted on the CRF or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started)
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, or observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable PCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date the PK samples were collected can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the PK samples at that visit, or the collection date can be collected on the PK CRF using the date (PCDAT) field.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether PK samples were collected
Question Text: Were PK samples collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate whether all of the PK samples in this group were collected.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable PCSTAT. If PCPERF="N", the value of PCSTAT will be "NOT DONE". If PCPERF="Y", PCSTAT should be null. PCTEST and PCTESTCD must reflect what tests were not done. A combination of SDTMIG variables (e.g., PCCAT and PCSCAT, PCTPT) is used to indicate that multiple tests were not done. In this situation, the SDTMIG variable PCTESTCD would be populated as PCALL and an appropriate test name (PCTEST) provided. See SDTMIG for additional information.
Implementation Notes: This general prompt question is used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing. This may be implemented at form level or sample level. These may be all samples of a particular type, or all samples taken for some purpose, and may need to be identified by the organization of the data on the form. Each sample collected could result in 1 or more tests performed, so there can be a one-to-one or one-to-many relationship between samples and tests/results.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation for why the data are not available
Question Text: What was the reason the PK sample was not collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason why a PK sample was not collected.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The reason the data are not available may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text. When PCREASND is used, the SDTMIG variable PCSTAT should also be populated in the SDTM-based dataset.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date of PK sample collection or the start date of PK sample collection over a period of time (protocol-defined time-point range), represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY)
Question Text: What was the date of the PK sample collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date when PK sample collection occurred using this format (DD-MON-YYYY). If left blank, "PCDATFL" for this specimen must be populated (or "PCPERF" must be flagged to indicate this sample was not collected).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete date is expected. The SDTMIG PCDTC variable contains either a date/time when a specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a specimen is collected over time.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of PK sample collection or start time for a specimen collected over a period of time (protocol-defined time-point range), represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss)
Question Text: What was the start time of the PK sample collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record start time of collection (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PCDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete time is expected. In interval collection, start can be added as needed to the question text, prompt and CRF directions. The SDTMIG PCDTC variable contains either a date/time when a specimen is collected at a point in time or the start date/time, when a specimen is collected over time.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end date of the specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY)
Question Text: What was the end date of the specimen collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the date when PK sample collection stopped using this format (DD-MON-YYYY)
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PCENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The end date of specimen collection may be determined from the date of visit and, if so, a separate assessment date field is not required.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The end time of the specimen collection, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss)
Question Text: What was the specimen collection end time?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record end time of collection (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH END DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PCENDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: A complete end time is expected. The SDTMIG variable PCENDTC variable contains the end date/time, when a specimen is collected over time. If there is no end date/time, the SDTMIG variable PCENDTC should be null.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
CDASHIG Variable Label: PK Sampling Planned Time Point Name
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A text description of planned time points when measurements should be taken, as defined in the protocol
Question Text: What was the planned time point of the PK sample collection?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the planned time-point labels for the PK sample collection, if not preprinted on the CRF. Note: Planned time points are often described as relative to the dosing of the study drug.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. See the SDTMIG for additional information on representing time points. The SDTMIG time-point anchors PCTPTREF (text description) and PCRFTDTC (date/time) may be needed, as well as SDTMIG variables PCTPTNUM, PCELTM.
Implementation Notes: Planned time points are needed to differentiate multiple sequential assessments. It is recommended that time points should be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then terms such as "Planned Time Point" can be included in the column heading.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication that the subject has abstained from food/water for the specified amount of time
Question Text: Was the subject fasting?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether the subject was fasting prior to the test being performed.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Results may be affected by whether the subject was fasting. Some study treatments may have a food effect, and it is important to know whether the dose was taken after the subject had fasted.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Indication of whether the testing conditions defined in the protocol were met (e.g., low fat diet)
Question Text: Were the protocol-defined testing conditions met?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record whether protocol-defined testing conditions were met.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. This information could be submitted in a SUPPPC dataset as the value of SUPPPC.QVAL where SUPPPC.QNAM ="PCCOND" and SUPP.PCLABEL= "Test Condition Met". Refer to the current SDTM and SDTMIG for instructions on placement of NSVs in SDTM domains.
Implementation Notes: This information is collected when the test results may be affected by whether conditions for testing were properly met. The specific testing conditions required should be preprinted on the CRF (e.g., "Did subject meet diet requirements?"). Examples: calorie fast, fluid fast, high-fat meal, low-fat meal, exercise. This may not be relevant for all tests.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An internal or external identifier (e.g., specimen identifier)
Question Text: What was the (PK) [reference identifier/accession number]?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen or accession number assigned.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: This can be used to reconcile CRF data. May be included for linking back to specimens (e.g., Specimen ID).

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The type of specimen used for a PK sample
Question Text: What was the specimen (material) type?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the specimen material type, if not preprinted on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The type of specimen used for a measure. Should be collected if not available elsewhere, or if required to differentiate multiple specimens.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Descriptive name of the analyte or specimen characteristics used to obtain the PK measurement or finding
Question Text: What was the test name?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the name of the measurement or finding, if not preprinted on the CRF. If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may provide additional instructions to ensure the data is entered as intended.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable PCTESTCD may be determined from the value collected in PCTEST. The SDTMIG variables PCTESTCD and PCTEST are required in the SDTM submission datasets. Use appropriate CDISC CT for the test and test code.
Implementation Notes: Sponsors typically collect tests related to the specimen characteristics on the CRF (e.g., Volume, pH). Results for tests on an analyte (e.g., Concentration) would typically be populated when the SDTM-based datasets are created. If analyte test results are collected on the CRF, the test would be the analyte name. It is recommended that test names be preprinted on the CRF rather than collected in a free-text field. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Test" can be included in the column heading.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
CDASHIG Variable Label: PK Sampling Result in Original Units
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Result of the measurement or finding as originally received or collected
Question Text: What was the result of the test?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the PK sampling test result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

Data Collection Scenario/Implementation: PK Sample Collection over a Time Interval
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The unit of the result as originally received or collected
Question Text: What was the unit of the result?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the PK sampling test result.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Both quantitative results and interpretive findings or summaries may be recorded here.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study.
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically pre-printed in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be pre-printed on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be pre-populated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be system-generated. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTMIG.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The name of a clinical encounter that encompasses planned and unplanned trial interventions, procedures, and assessments that may be performed on a subject.
Question Text: What is the visit name?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: The name of the clinical encounter is typically pre-printed or displayed within the EDC for any visit-based data collection, most often in Findings domains. This Visit text description is then available in any EDC data extract for that Findings domain.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Date the clinical encounter occurred (or started).
Question Text: What [is/was] the date of the visit?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the [date/start date] of the visit using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This field is not an SDTM variable. The date of a measurement, test, observation can be determined from the date/time of visit (VISDAT/VISTIM) and then concatenating the CDASH VISDAT/VISTIM components and populating the SDTMIG variable PEDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date of the physical examination can be determined from the visit date variable (VISDAT) and applying that date to all of the physical examination findings at that visit, or the collection date can be included collected on the PE CRF using the date (PEDAT) field.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether a planned physical examination was performed.
Question Text: Was the physical examination performed?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If the physical examination was performed as planned, select Yes; otherwise, select No.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to derive a value into the SDTMIG variable PESTAT. If PEPERF="N" the value of PESTAT="NOT DONE". If PEPERF="Y", then the actual physical exam results would be reported by body system (see PERES). PECAT, PESCAT, PETEST and PETESTCD must reflect what tests were not done. If used for an entire CRF or other set of multiple tests with PECAT and PESCAT, PETESTCD=PEALL.
Implementation Notes: This general prompt question is used as a data management tool to verify that missing results are confirmed missing. Used to ask if the physical exam was performed at the overall subject level at the specified time point. If this field is used, the result should only be mapped to PESTAT if the overall examination (at the subject level) was not performed. If the overall examination was performed, then the value of PESTAT would be null for each examined body systems and "NOT DONE" for any body systems not examined (see PERES).

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A grouping of topic-variable values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was the category of the physical examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the physical examination category, or record if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. The CRF can capture different types of physical exams using PECAT (e.g., GENERAL, OPHTHAMOLOGIC, NEUROLOGICAL). This may be pre-printed on the CRF. If PECAT is not collected (e.g., it is evident from the protocol design), it could be populated when creating SDTM-based datasets.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sub-division of the PECAT values based on user-defined characteristics.
Question Text: What was subcategory of the physical examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the physical examination subcategory, or record if not pre-printed on the CRF.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Sponsor-defined controlled terminology. The CRF can capture the different subtypes of PE categories using PESCAT. This may be pre-printed on the CRF. If PESCAT is not collected (e.g. it is evident from the protocol design), it could be populated when creating SDTM-based datasets. PESCAT can only be used if there is a PECAT, and it must be a subcategorization of PECAT.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The date when the physical examination was performed, represented in an unambiguous date format (e.g., DD-MON-YYYY).
Question Text: What was the date of the physical examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record complete date of examination using this format (DD-MON-YYYY).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PEDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: The date of examination may be determined from the date of the visit (VISDAT); if so, a separate assessment date field is not required.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The time of examination, represented in an unambiguous time format (e.g., hh:mm:ss).
Question Text: What was the time of the physical examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the time of examination (as complete as possible).
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. For the SDTM submission dataset, concatenate all collected CDASH DATE and TIME components and populate the SDTMIG variable PEDTC in ISO 8601 format.
Implementation Notes: Collect time if it is relevant for the analysis.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A sponsor-defined identifier. In CDASH, this is typically used for pre-printed or auto-generated numbers on the CRF, or any other type of identifier that does not already have a defined CDASH identifier field.
Question Text: [Sponsor-defined question]
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: If collected on the CRF, the sponsor may insert instructions to ensure each record has a unique identifier.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. May be used to create RELREC to link this record with a record in another domain.
Implementation Notes: Because SPID is a sponsor-defined identifier, conformance to Question Text or Item Prompt is not applicable. Typically used as an identifier in a data query to communicate clearly to the site the specific record in question or to reconcile data. May be used to record pre-printed number (e.g. line number, record number) on the CRF. This field may be populated by the sponsor's data collection system.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Name of the body system.
Question Text: What was the body system examined?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Per protocol, perform physical examinations of specified body systems.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column. The SDTMIG variable PETESTCD may be determined from the value collected in PETEST.
Implementation Notes: Sponsors should preprint all body systems to be examined on the CRF. The use of a complete list of body systems eliminates the need for an Other, Specify category; any abnormalities identified would fall under 1 of the specified categories. If the form is laid out as a grid, then words such as "Body System" can be included in the column heading.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Overall assessment of examined body system.
Question Text: Were the results normal, abnormal, or not done?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the overall assessment for each exam category/body system listed.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into the SDTMIG variable PEORRES. If PERES="Normal", populate PEORRES with the value of PERES. If PERES="Abnormal", populate PEORRES with the value of PEDESC.
Implementation Notes: If the examined body system is normal, then the value in PEORRES should be "NORMAL". If the body system is not examined, then the value in PEORRES should be Null and the value in PESTAT should be "NOT DONE". If the examined body system is abnormal, then the value of PEORRES should contain the text of the abnormal findings (PEDESC). If the sponsor's data collection system allows for up-front recording of the abnormality and status using a single variable, then the SDTM variable name PEORRES may be used in place of CDASH variable names PERES and PEDESC. When creating SDTM-based datasets, PESTRESC is the standardized value for PEORRES and is populated for any record where PEORRES is not null. If the abnormal findings are coded using a dictionary, then PESTRESC should be the dictionary preferred term; if not coded, PEORRES.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Text description of any abnormal findings.
Question Text: If the result was abnormal, what were the findings?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record all abnormal findings for the given body system in the space provided.
Mapping Instructions: This does not map directly to an SDTMIG variable. May be used to populate a value into the SDTMIG variable PEORRES. If PERES="Normal", populate PEORRES with the value of PERES. If PERES="Abnormal", populate PEORRES with the value of PEDESC.
Implementation Notes: If the examined body system is normal, then the value in PEORRES should be "NORMAL". If the body system is not examined, then the value in PEORRES should be Null and the value in PESTAT should be "NOT DONE". If the examined body system is abnormal, then the value of PEORRES should contain the text of the abnormal findings (PEDESC). If the sponsor's data collection system allows for up-front recording of the abnormality and status using a single variable, then the SDTM variable name PEORRES may be used in place of CDASH variable names PERES and PEDESC.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An indication of whether the physical examination abnormality is clinically significant.
Question Text: Was the physical examination result clinically significant?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Was the physical examination result clinically significant? Select Yes or No.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: If this level of information is needed for reconciliation with adverse events, this field may be added to the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: The role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Question Text: Who was the evaluator?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Select the role of the person who provided the evaluation (e.g., INVESTIGATOR, ADJUDICATION COMMITTEE, VENDOR).
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Used only for results that are subjective (e.g., assigned by a person or a group). May be pre-printed or collected. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: An explanation of why the data are not available.
Question Text: What is the reason that data were not collected?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Provide the reason the assessment was not done.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Captures the reason why the measurement or test was not done. The reason may be chosen from a sponsor-defined list (e.g., broken equipment, subject refused) or entered as free text.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Body system or organ class that is involved for a finding from the standard hierarchy for dictionary-coded results.
Question Text: What is/was the [body system/ organ system]?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: PEBODSYS should be assigned using a coding system. If included on the CRF, it is prepopulated and must be paired by the sponsor with specific verbatim terms. If not included on the CRF, PEBODSYS is assigned through the coding process.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: If the value for PEORRES is modified for coding purposes, then the modified text is placed here.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This is not a data collection field that would appear on the CRF. Sponsors will populate this through the coding process. PEMODIFY contains any modified text used for coding. Used only when the reported abnormalities in PEORRES are coded to a dictionary. This is in contrast to Events and Interventions domains, where the topic variable (TERM or TRT) is modified for coding.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A description of the anatomical location of the subject, relevant to the collection of physical examination.
Question Text: What was the anatomical location of the body system examined or the finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the anatomical location of the abnormal finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected or pre-printed when the sponsor needs to identify the specific anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF. LAT, DIR, and PORTOT are used to further describe the anatomical location.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the side of the body.
Question Text: What was the side of the anatomical location of the body system examined or the finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the side of the anatomical location of the abnormal finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be pre-printed or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific side of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier further detailing the position of the anatomical location, relative to the center of the body, organ, or specimen.
Question Text: What was the directionality of the anatomical location of the of the body system examined or the finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the directionality of the anatomical location of the abnormal finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: May be pre-printed or collected when the sponsor needs to identify the directionality of the anatomical location. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Qualifier for anatomical location, further detailing the distribution (i.e., arrangement of, apportioning of).
Question Text: What was the portion or totality of the anatomical location of the body system examined or the finding?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Indicate the proportionality of the anatomical location of the of the abnormal finding.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Collected when the sponsor needs to identify the specific portionality for the anatomical locations. Sponsors may collect the data using a subset list of controlled terminology on the CRF.

CDASHIG Variable Label: PE Method of Test or Examination
DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: Method of the test or examination.
Question Text: What was the method used for the test or examination?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the method of test or examination.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: This information may be collected when more than 1 method is possible, and collecting the method used is necessary.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a study
Question Text: What is the study identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Although this field is not typically captured on a CRF, it should be displayed clearly on the CRF and/or in the EDC system. This field can be included in the database or populated during SDTM-based dataset creation before submission.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique identifier for a site within a study.
Question Text: What is the site identifier?
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically preprinted in the header of each CRF page for single-site studies. For studies with multiple sites, this field may be left blank so that the number can be recorded by the site, or it may be preprinted on the CRFs that are shipped to each site. \n EDC: This should be prepopulated.

DRAFT CDASHIG Definition: A unique subject identifier within a site and a study.
Question Text: What [is/was] the (study) [subject/participant] identifier?
Case Report Form Completion Instructions: Record the identifier for the subject.
Mapping Instructions: Maps directly to the SDTMIG variable listed in the SDTMIG Target column.
Implementation Notes: Paper: This is typically recorded in the header of each CRF page. EDC: The subject identifiers may be provided to the site using a prepopulated list in the system. This CDASH variable is typically collected in all CDASH domains. However, this CDASH variable is populated only in the SDTMIG DM domain. For more information, refer to the SDTM.
